div1.head: θαάσσω
div1.sense: to sit, Hom.; Epic inf. θαασσέμεν Od.

div1.head: θαέομαι
div1.etym: Doric for θηέομαι, Ionic form of θεάομαι, Pind., Theocr.

div1.head: θάημα
div1.sense: a sight, wonder, Theocr.

div1.head: θαἰμάτια
div1.sense: crasis for τὰ ἱμάτια.

div1.head: θαἰματίδια
div1.sense: crasis for τὰ ἱματίδια.

div1.head: θαιρός
div1.sense: the hinge of a door or gate, Il.

div1.head: θακέω
div1.sense: to sit, Hdt., Trag.; c. acc. cogn., θακοῦντι παγκρατεῖς ἕδρας sitting on imperial throne, Aesch.: suppliants, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: θάκημα
div1.sense: a sitting, esp. as a suppliant, Soph.
a seat, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: θάκησις
div1.sense: a sitting, sitting-place, Soph.

div1.head: θᾶκος
div1.sense: a seat, chair, Hom.; θῶκοι ἀμπαυστήριοι seats for resting, Hdt.; θᾶκος κραιπνόσυτος, of a winged car, Aesch., etc.
a chair of office, Ar.
a privy, Theophr.
in Hom. a sitting in council, a council, Od.; θῶκόνδε to the council, Od.; ἐν θώκῳ κατήμενος sitting in council, Hdt.

div1.head: θαλαμήϊος
div1.sense: of or for a θάλαμος, Hes.

div1.head: θαλάμη
div1.sense: a lurking-place, den, hole, cave, Od., Eur.; of the grave, Eur.
= θάλαμος III, Luc.

div1.head: θαλαμηπόλος
div1.sense: a chamber-maid, waiting maid, Od., Aesch.
a eunuch of the bed chamber, Plut.
rarely, a bridegroom, Soph.
as adj. bridal, Anth.

div1.head: θαλαμιός
div1.sense: of or belonging to the θάλαμος:—as Subst.,
θαλαμιός, ὁ, θαλαμίτης, Thuc.
θαλαμία, Ionic -ιή (sub. κώπη) , the oar of the θαλαμίτης, Ar.
(sub. ὀπή) the hole in the shipʼs side, through which this oar worked, διὰ θαλαμιῆς διελεῖν τινα to place a man so that his upper half projected through this hole, Hdt.

div1.head: θαλαμίτης
div1.sense: one of the rowers on the lowest bench of a trireme, who had the shortest oars and the least pay; cf. ζυγίτης, θρανίτης.

div1.head: θάλαμόνδε
div1.sense: to the bed-chamber, Od.

div1.head: θάλαμος
div1.sense: an inner room or chamber:
generally, the womenʼs apartment, inner part of the house, Hom., Hdt.
a chamber in this part of the house:
a bed-room, Il.:— the bride-chamber, Il., Soph., etc.
a store-room, Hom., Xen.
generally, a chamber, room, Od.

metaph., ὁ παγκοίτας θ. of the grave, Soph.; τυμβήρης θ. of the ark of Danae, Soph.; θάλαμοι ὑπὸ γῆς the realms below, Aesch.; θ. Ἀμφιτρίτης of the sea, Soph.; ἀρνῶν θ. their folds or pens, Eur., etc.
the lowest part of the ship, in which the θαλαμῖται sat, the hold.
a shrine, temple, Anth.

div1.head: θάλασσα
div1.sense: the sea, Hom., etc.; when he uses it of a particular sea, he means the Mediterranean, opp. to Ὠκεανός;— Hdt. calls the Mediterranean ἥδε ἡ θάλασσα; so, ἡ παρʼ ἡμῖν θάλ. Plat.; κατὰ θάλασσαν by sea, opp. to πεζῇ by land, Hdt.; to κατὰ γῆς, Thuc.:—metaph., κακῶν θ. a sea of troubles, Aesch.
a well of salt water, said to be produced by a stroke of Poseidonʼs trident, in the Acropolis at Athens, Hdt.

div1.head: θαλασσεύω
div1.sense: to be at sea, keep the sea, Thuc.; τὰ θαλαττεύοντα τῆς νεὼς μέρη the parts under water, Plut.

div1.head: θαλάσσιος
div1.sense: of, in, on or from the sea, belonging to it, Lat. marinus, οὔ σφι θαλάσσια ἔργα μεμήλει, of the Arcadians, Il.; κορῶναι τῇσίν τε θαλ. ἔργα μέμηλεν, i. e. which live by fishing, Od.:— θαλάσσια sea-animals, opp. to χερσαῖα, Hdt.; πεζοί τε καὶ θαλ. landsmen and seamen, Aesch.; θαλ. ἐκρίπτειν τινά to throw one into the sea, Soph.
skilled in the sea, nautical, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: θαλασσοκοπέω
div1.sense: to strike the sea with the oar: metaph. to make a splash, Ar.

div1.head: θαλασσοκρατέω
div1.sense: to be master of the sea, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: θαλασσοκράτωρ
div1.sense: master of the sea, Hdt., Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: θαλασσόπλαγκτος
div1.sense: made to wander oʼer the sea, sea-tost, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: θαλασσόπληκτος
div1.sense: sea-beaten, Aesch.

div1.head: θαλασσοπόρος
div1.sense: sea-faring, Anth.

div1.head: θαλασσουργός
div1.sense: one who works on the sea, a fisherman, seaman, Xen.

div1.head: θαλασσόω
div1.sense: to make or change into sea: Mid. to be a sea-faring man, Luc.

div1.head: θάλεα
div1.sense: good cheer, happy thoughts, θαλέων ἐμπλησάμενος κῆρ Il.

div1.head: θαλέθω
div1.sense: to bloom, flourish, Hom. only in part.; of trees, Od.; of men, Od.; of swine, θαλέθοντες ἀλοιφῇ swelling, wantoning in fat, Il.

div1.head: θάλεια
div1.sense: fem. adj. blooming, luxuriant, goodly, bounteous, of banquets, θεῶν ἐν δαιτὶ θαλείῃ Od., etc. No masc. θάλυς occurs, θαλερός being used instead.
as prop. n. Θάλεια, ἡ, one of the Muses, the blooming one, Hes.; also Θαλίη, Anth.

div1.head: θαλερός
div1.sense: blooming, fresh, of young persons, Hom.; θ. γάμος the marriage of a youthful pair, Od.

of the body, fresh, vigorous, Il.; θ. χαίτη luxuriant hair, Il.; θ. ἀλοιφή rich, abundant fat, Od.;—then of other things, θαλερὸν κατὰ δάκρυ χέουσα shedding big tears, Il.; θ. γόος the thick and frequent sob, Od.; θαλερὴ φωνή a full, rich voice, Hom.

div1.head: Θαλῆς
div1.sense: Thales of Miletus, Hdt.

div1.head: θαλία
div1.sense: abundance, plenty, good cheer, Il.; in pl. festivities, Od., Hdt.

div1.head: θαλλός
div1.sense: a young shoot, young branch, Od., Soph., etc.:—of the young olive-shoot carried by suppliants, Hdt., Trag.; ἱκτὴρ θ. Eur.; also, θαλλοῦ στέφανος the olive- wreath worn at festivals, Aeschin.

div1.head: θαλλοφόρος
div1.sense: carrying young olive-shoots, Ar.

div1.head: θάλλω
div1.sense: to bloom, abound, to be luxuriant, of fruit-trees, Od., Soph., etc.; often in part. perf. τεθηλώς, Epic fem. τεθαλυῖα, as adj., luxuriant, exuberant, Od.; c. acc. cogn., οὐ δένδρεʼ ἔθαλλεν χῶρος the place grew no trees, θαλλούσης βίον ἐλαίας Aesch.
of other natural objects, τεθαλυῖα ἐέρση the fresh or copious dew, Od.; τεθαλυῖα ἀλοιφῆι rich with fat, Il.; εἰλαπίνηι τεθαλυίηι at a sumptuous feast, Il.
of men, to bloom, flourish, Hes., Soph., etc.
in bad sense, to be active, νόσος ἀεὶ τέθηλε Soph.; πήματα ἀεὶ θάλλοντα Soph.

div1.head: θάλος
div1.sense: in metaph. sense of young persons, like ἔρνος (q. v.), φίλον θάλος dear child of mine, Il.; τοιόνδε θάλος so fair a scion of their house, Od.

div1.head: θαλπιάω
div1.sense: to be or become warm, εὖ θαλπιόων (Epic part.) right warm and comfortable, Od.

div1.head: θαλπνός
div1.sense: warming, fostering, Pind.

div1.head: θάλπος
div1.sense: warmth, heat, esp. summer heat, Aesch.; θ. θεοῦ the sunʼs heat, Soph.; μεσημβρινοῖσι θάλπεσιν with the meridian rays (cf. Lat. soles), Aesch.
metaph. a sting, smart, caused by an arrow, Soph., Anth.

div1.head: θαλπτήριος
div1.sense: warming, Anth.

div1.head: θάλπω
div1.sense: to heat, soften by heat, Od.:—Pass., ἐτήκετο, κασσίτερος ὣς θαλφθείς Hes.: metaph. to be softened, λόγοις Ar.
to heat, warm, without any notion of softening, καῦμʼ ἔθαλπε (sc. ἡμᾶς) Soph.:—Pass., θάλπεσθαι τοῦ θέρους to be warm in summer, Xen.:—metaph. to be alive, Pind.
to warm at the fire, dry, Soph., Eur.
metaph. of passion, to heat, inflame, Aesch., Soph.
to cherish, comfort, foster, Theocr.

div1.head: θαλπωρή
div1.sense: warming: metaph. comfort, consolation, source of hope, Hom.

div1.head: θαλύσια
div1.sense: the firstlings of the harvest, offerings of first fruits, Il., Theocr.

div1.head: θαλυσιάς
div1.sense: fem. adj. of or for the θαλύσια, Theocr.

div1.head: θαμά
div1.sense: often, oft-times, Hom., etc.

div1.head: θαμβαίνω
div1.sense: to be astonished at, Hhymn.

div1.head: θαμβέω
div1.sense: to be astounded, amazed, Hom., Soph., Eur.
c. acc. to be astonished at, marvel at, Od., Pind.
Causal, to surprise:—Pass., τεθαμβημένος astounded, Plut.

div1.head: θάμβος
div1.sense: astonishment, amazement, Hom., Attic

div1.head: θαμέες
div1.sense: poet. adj. only in pl., crowded, close-set, thick, Hom.

div1.head: θαμίζω
div1.sense: to come often, Lat. frequentare, Hom., Xen.
to be often or constantly engaged with or in a thing, Od.; οὔτι κομιζόμενός γε θάμιζεν he was not wont to be so cared for, Od.; μινύρεται θαμίζουσα ἀηδών mourns often or constantly, Soph.

div1.head: θαμινός
div1.sense: frequent, in neut. pl. θαμινά :—asAdv. = θαμά, Pind., Attic

div1.head: θάμνος
div1.sense: a bush, shrub, Lat. arbustum, Hom.; in pl. a copse, thicket, Hom., Attic

div1.head: θανάσιμος
div1.sense: deadly, Trag., etc.
of or belonging to death, θαν. αἷμα (as we say) the life- blood, Aesch.; μέλψασα θ. γόον having sung my death- song, Aesch.
of persons, near death, Soph., Plat.: subject to death, mortal, Plat.: also dead, Soph.

div1.head: θανατάω
div1.sense: Desiderat. of θανεῖν, to desire to die, Plat.

div1.head: θανατηφόρος
div1.sense: death-bringing, mortal, Aesch., Soph., etc.

div1.head: θανατικός
div1.sense: deadly, θ. δίκη sentence of death, Plut.

div1.head: θανατόεις
div1.sense: deadly, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: θάνατος
div1.sense: death, Hom., etc.; θ. τινος the death threatened by him, Od.; θάνατόνδε to death, Il., etc.

in Attic, θάνατον καταγιγνώσκειν τινός to pass sentence of death on one, Thuc.; θανάτου κρίνεσθαι to be tried for oneʼs life, Thuc.:—ellipt., τὴν ἐπὶ θανάτῳ κεκοσμημένος (sc. στολήν) Hdt.; δῆσαί τινα τὴν ἐπὶ θανάτου (sc. δέσιν) Hdt.; τοῖς Ἀθηναίοις ἐπιτρέψαι περὶ σφῶν αὐτῶν πλὴν θανάτου for any penalty short of death, Thuc.
pl. θάνατοι, kinds of death, Od.; or the deaths of several persons or even of one person, Trag.
as prop. n., Θάνατος Death, twin-brother of Sleep, Il.
= νεκρός, Anth.

div1.head: θανατούσια
div1.sense: sc. ἱερά, τά, a feast of the dead, Luc.

div1.head: θανατόω
div1.etym: fut. mid. in pass. sense θανατώσοιτο Xen.
div1.sense: to put to death, τινά Hdt., Attic
metaph. to mortify the flesh, NTest.
to put to death by sentence of law, Plat.:—Pass., Xen.

div1.head: θανάτωσις
div1.sense: a putting to death, Thuc.

div1.head: θάομαι
div1.sense: Dep.
to wonder at, admire, Od.
later, to gaze on, see, 2nd pl. θᾶσθε, Ar.; imperat. θάεο Anth.: Doric fut. part. θασόμενος Theocr.; aor1 imperat. θᾶσαι Ar.; inf. θάσασθαι Theocr.

div1.head: θαπτέος
div1.sense: one must bury, Soph.

div1.head: θάπτω
div1.sense: to pay the last dues to a corpse, to honour with funeral rites, i. e. in early times by burning the body, Hom.: then, simply, to bury, inter, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: θαρσαλέος
div1.sense: bold, of good courage, ready, daring, undaunted, Il., Attic: —τὸ θαρσαλέον confidence, Thuc.:—so in adv., θαρραλέως ἔχειν to be of good courage, Plat., Xen.
in bad sense, overbold, audacious, Od.
that which may be ventured on, Plat.

div1.head: θαρσαλεότης
div1.sense: boldness, Plut.

div1.head: θαρσέω
div1.sense: to be of good courage, take courage, Il., etc.:—in bad sense, to be over-bold, audacious, Thuc., Plat.; θάρσει, θαρσεῖτε, take courage! cheer up, Hom., etc.; θαρσήσας with good courage, Il.; so, θαρσῶν Hdt., Attic:—also, τὸ τεθαρρηκός confidence, Plut.
c. acc., θάρσει τόνδε γʼ ἄεθλον take heart for this struggle, Od.; θ. θάνατον Plat.; θ. μάχην to venture a fight, Xen.:—c. acc. pers. to have confidence in, Xen.:—so also, θαρσεῖν τινι Hdt.
c. inf. to believe confidently that, Soph.; also, to make bold or venture to do, Xen.

div1.head: θάρσησις
div1.sense: confidence in a thing, Thuc.

div1.head: θάρσος
div1.sense: courage, boldness, Hom., Attic; θ. τινός courage to do a thing, Aesch., Soph.
that which gives courage, θάρση grounds of confidence, Eur., Plat.
in bad sense, audacity, Il.: cf. θράσος.

div1.head: θαρσούντως
div1.etym: adverb from pres. part. of θαρσέω
div1.sense: boldly, courageously, Xen.

div1.head: θάρσυνος
div1.sense: c. dat. relying on a thing, Il.

div1.head: θαρσύνω
div1.sense: Causal of θαρσέω, to encourage, cheer, θάρσυνον (aor1 imperat.) Il.; θαρσύνεσκε (Ionic imperf.) Il.; so Hdt., Thuc., etc.
intr. θάρσυνε be of good courage, Soph.

div1.head: Θάσιος
div1.sense: of or from Thasos, Thasian, οἶνος Ar.:— ἡ Θασία ἅλμη Thasian pickled fish, Ar.

div1.head: θάσσων
div1.sense: quicker, swifter: neut. θᾶσσον as adv., more quickly.

div1.head: θάσσω
div1.sense: to sit, sit idle;— c. acc. sedis, θάσσειν θρόνον Soph., etc.; c. acc. cogn., θ. δυστήνους ἕδρας to sit in wretched posture, Eur.

div1.head: θαυμάζω
div1.sense: to wonder, marvel, be astonied, Il., etc.
c. acc. to look on with wonder and amazement, to wonder at, marvel at, Hom., Hdt., Attic
to honour, admire, worship, Lat. admirari, observare, Od., Hdt., Attic:—θ. τινά τινος for a thing, Thuc.; ἐπί τινι Xen.
c. gen. to wonder at, marvel at, Thuc., etc.; θ. σοῦ λέγοντος Plat.
c. dat. rei, to wonder at, Thuc.
c. acc. et inf., θ. σε πενθεῖν Eur.
Pass. to be looked at with wonder, Hdt.; θαυμάζεται μὴ παρών, i. e. I keep wondering that he is not present, Soph.
to be admired, Hdt.; τὰ εἰκότα θ. to receive proper marks of respect, Thuc.

div1.head: θαυμαίνω
div1.sense: to admire, gaze upon, Od., Pind.

div1.head: θαῦμα
div1.sense: of objects, whatever one regards with wonder, a wonder, marvel, Hom., Hes.; θαῦμα, of Polypheme, Od.; θαῦμα βροτοῖσι, of a beautiful woman, Od.; c. inf., θαῦμα ἰδέσθαι or ἰδεῖν a wonder to behold, Od., Eur.; καὶ θαῦμά γʼ οὐδέν and no wonder, Ar.: —θῶμα ποιεῖσθαί τι Hdt.:—in pl., θαύματʼ ἐμοὶ κλύειν Aesch.; θαυμάτων κρείσσονα or πέρα things more than wondrous, Eur.
in pl. also jugglersʼ tricks, mountebank-gambols, Xen., etc.
of the feeling, wonder, astonishment, Od., etc.; ἐν θώματι εἶναι or γίγνεσθαι to be astonished, Hdt., Thuc.; τινός at a thing, Hdt.

div1.head: θαυμάσιος
div1.sense: wondrous, wonderful, marvellous, Hes., Hdt.; θαυμάσια wonders, marvels, Hdt., Plat.: θαυμάσιόν ἐστι, c. inf., Ar.; θαυμάσιος τὸ κάλλος marvellous for beauty, Xen.; θαυμάσιον ὅσον wonderfully much, Plat.; θαυμάσια ἡλίκα Dem.
adv. -ίως, wonderfully, i. e. exceedingly, Ar.; often with ὡς added, θ. ὡς ἄθλιος marvellously wretched, Plat.
admirable, excellent, with slight irony, Plat., Dem.; ὦ θαυμασιώτατε ἄνθρωπε, in scorn, Xen.

div1.head: θαυμασιουργέω
div1.sense: to work wonders, Xen.

div1.head: θαυμασμός
div1.sense: a marvelling, Plut., etc.

div1.head: θαυμαστέος
div1.sense: to be admired, Plat.
neut. θαυμαστέον, one must admire, Eur.

div1.head: θαυμαστής
div1.sense: an admirer, Arist.

div1.head: θαυμαστικός
div1.sense: inclined to wonder or admire, Arist.

div1.head: θαυμαστός
div1.sense: wondrous, wonderful, marvellous, Hhymn., Hdt., Attic:—c. acc., θαυμαστὸς τὸ κάλλος Plat.; c. gen., θ. τῆς ἐπιεικείας Plut.; c. dat., πλήθει Plut.:—foll. by a Relat., θαυμαστὸν ὅσον, Lat. mirum quantum, Plat., etc.; θαυμαστὸν ἡλίκον Dem.:—adv. -τῶς, θαυμαστῶς ὡς σφόδρα Plat.
admirable, excellent, Pind., Soph.

div1.head: θαυματοποιέω
div1.sense: to work wonders, Luc.

div1.head: θαυματοποιία
div1.sense: conjuring, juggling, Plat.

div1.head: θαυματοποιός
div1.sense: wonder-working:—as Subst. a conjuror, juggler, Plat., Dem.

div1.head: θάψινος
div1.sense: yellow-coloured, yellow, sallow, Ar.

div1.head: θάψος
div1.sense: a plant or wood used for dyeing yellow, brought from Thapsos, Theocr.

div1.head: θάω
div1.sense: παρέχουσιν γάλα θῆσθαι they give milk to suck, Od.; aor 1, θήσατο μαζόν he sucked the breast, Il.; part., θησάμενος sucking, Hhymn.
Causal, to suckle a child, Hhymn.

div1.head: θέαινα
div1.sense: a goddess, Hom.

div1.head: θέαμα
div1.sense: that which is seen, a sight, show, spectacle, Trag., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: θεάμων
div1.sense: a spectator, Anth.

div1.head: θεάομαι
div1.sense: Dep.
to look on, gaze at, view, behold, Hom., Hdt., Attic; ἐθεᾶτο τὴν θέσιν τῆς πόλεως reconnoitred it, Thuc.
to view as spectators, οἱ θεώμενοι the spectators in a theatre, Ar.:—metaph., θ. τὸν πόλεμον to be spectators of the war, Hdt.
θ. τὸ στράτευμα to review it, Xen.

div1.head: θεά
div1.sense: fem. of θεός, a goddess, Hom.; often with another Subst., θεὰ μήτηρ Il.:— τὰ θεά in dual are Demeter and Persephone (Ceres and Proserpine) Soph.; αἱ σεμναὶ θεαί the Furies, Soph.

div1.head: θέα
div1.sense: a seeing, looking at, view, θέης ἄξιος ἀξιοθέητος, Hdt.; θέαν λαβεῖν to take or get a view, Soph.
aspect, διαπρεπὴς τὴν θέαν Eur.
that which is seen, a sight, spectacle, Trag.
the place for seeing from, a seat in the theatre, Aeschin., Dem.

div1.head: θεάριον
div1.sense: the place where the θεωροί met, Pind.

div1.head: θεατέος
div1.sense: to be seen, Plat.
θεατέον, one must see, Plat.

div1.head: θεατής
div1.sense: one who sees, a spectator, Hdt., Eur., etc.

div1.head: θεατός
div1.sense: to be seen, Soph., Plat.

div1.head: θεατρίζω
div1.sense: to bring on the stage:— Pass. to be made a show of, a gazing-stock, NTest.

div1.head: θεατρικός
div1.sense: of or for the theatre, theatrical, Arist., Plut.

div1.head: θέατρον
div1.sense: a place for seeing, esp. a theatre, Hdt., Thuc., etc.
collective for οἱ θεαταί, the people in the theatre, the spectators, "the house, " Hdt., Ar.
= θέαμα, a show, spectacle, θ. γενηθῆναι, θεατρίζεσθαι, NTest.

div1.head: θεήϊος
div1.sense: divine, Bion.

div1.head: θεήλατος
div1.sense: driven or hunted by a god, Aesch.
sent or caused by a god, Hdt., Soph.; ἔκ τινος θεηλάτου from some destiny, Eur.
built for the gods, like θεόδμητος, Eur.

div1.head: θεημοσύνη
div1.sense: contemplation: a problem, Anth.

div1.head: θειάζω
div1.sense: to practice divinations, Thuc.

div1.head: θειασμός
div1.sense: practice of divination, Thuc.

div1.head: Θείβαθεν
div1.sense: from Thebes, Ar.

div1.head: Θείβαθι
div1.sense: at Thebes, Ar.

div1.head: θειλόπεδον
div1.sense: a sunny spot in the vineyard, on which the grapes were suffered to dry, so as to make raisins, Od.

div1.head: θείνω
div1.etym: aor1 ἔθεινα; the other moods are taken from an aor2 ἔθενον which does not occur in ind.
div1.sense: to strike, wound, Hom., Eur.:—Pass., θεινομένου πρὸς οὔδεϊ stricken to earth, Od.
metaph., θείνειν ὀνείδει Aesch.
intr. of ships, θ. ἐπʼ ἀκτᾶς to strike on the shore, Aesch.

div1.head: θειόδομος
div1.sense: built by gods, Anth.

div1.head: θεῖον
div1.sense: brimstone, Lat. sulfur, used to fumigate and purify, Hom.; δεινὴ δὲ θεείου γίγνεται ὀδμή, from a thunderbolt, Il.

div1.head: θεῖος
div1.etym: comp. and Sup. θειότερος, -ότατος, θεώτερος being comp. of θεός
div1.sense: of or from the gods, sent by the gods, issuing from them, divine, Hom., Hdt., Attic; θ. νόσος of a whirlwind, Soph.; θείᾳ τινὶ μοίρᾳ by divine intervention, Xen.; so, θείῃ τύχῃ Hdt.:— appointed of God, βασιλῆες Od.
belonging or sacred to a god, in honour of a god, holy, Hom.: under divine protection, δόμος Hom.; of heralds and minstrels, Hom.

like θεσπέσιος, ἱερός, Lat. divinus, of anything more than human, wondrous: of heroes, divinely strong, great, beautiful, etc., Hom.; and as a mere mark of respect, excellent, θεῖος ὑφορβός Od.; so, θ. πρήγματα marvellous things, Hdt.; ἐν τοῖσι θειότατον one of the most marvellous things, Hdt.; so, at Sparta, θεῖος (or rather σεῖος) ἀνήρ was a title of distinction, Plat., Arist.
as Subst., θεῖον, ου, τό, the Divine Being, the Divinity, Deity, Hdt., Aesch.
θεῖα, τά, divine things, the acts and attributes of the gods, the course of providence, Soph., Ar., etc.: religious observances, Xen.; ἔρρει τὰ θεῖα religion is out of date, Soph.
adv. θείως, by divine providence, Xen.; θειοτέρως by special providence, Hdt.

div1.head: θεῖος2
div1.sense: oneʼs fatherʼs or motherʼs brother, uncle, Lat. patruus and avunculus, Eur., etc.

div1.head: θειότης
div1.sense: divine nature, divinity, Plut.

div1.head: θειόω
div1.sense: to smoke with brimstone, fumigate and purify thereby, Od.:—Mid., δῶμα θεειοῦται he fumigates his house, Od.: generally, to purify, hallow, Eur.

div1.head: θελγεσίμυθος
div1.sense: soft-speaking, Anth.

div1.head: θέλγητρον
div1.sense: a charm or spell, Eur., Luc.

div1.head: θέλγω
div1.sense: properly, to stroke or touch with magic power, Lat. mulcere, and so to charm, enchant, spell-bind, of Hermes, who with his magic wand ἀνδρῶν ὄμματα θέλγει, lays men in a charmed sleep, Hom.; of the sorceress Circe, Od., etc.
in bad sense, to cheat, cozen, Hom., Soph.
to produce by spells, ἀοιδαὶ θέλξαν νιν (sc. εὐφροσύναν) Pind.; γαλήνην θ. ἀνηνεμίην Anth.

div1.head: θέλημα
div1.sense: will, NTest.

div1.head: θέλησις
div1.sense: a willing, will, NTest.

div1.head: θελκτήριον
div1.sense: a charm, spell, enchantment, of the girdle of Aphrodite, Il.; θεῶν θελκτήριον a means of soothing the gods, Od.; νεκροῖς θελκτήρια, of offerings to the Manes, Eur.

div1.head: θελκτήριος
div1.sense: charming, enchanting, soothing, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: θελκτήρ
div1.sense: a soother, charmer, Hhymn.

div1.head: θελξίνοος
div1.sense: charming the heart, Anth.

div1.head: θελξίπικρος
div1.sense: sweetly painful, Anth.

div1.head: θέμεθλα
div1.sense: the foundations, lowest part, bottom, ὀφθαλμοῖο θέμεθλα the very bottom, roots of the eye, Il.; Ἄμμωνος θέμ. the place where Ammon stands, i. e. his temple, Pind.; Παγγαίου θέμ. the roots of Mt. Pangaeus, Pind.

div1.head: θεμέλιος
div1.sense: of or for the foundation, Ar.:—as Subst., θεμέλιος (sub. λίθος) a foundation, οἱ θεμέλιοι the foundations, Thuc.; ἐκ τῶν θεμελίων from the foundations, Thuc.

div1.head: θεμελιόω
div1.sense: to lay the foundation of, found firmly, Xen.:—Pass. to have the foundations laid, NTest.: metaph., βασιλεία καλῶς θεμελιωθεῖσα Diod.; ἡγεμονία κάλλιστα τεθεμελιωμένη Diod.; ἐν ἀγαπῇ τεθ. NTest.

div1.head: θεμερῶπις
div1.sense: of grave and serious aspect, Aesch.

div1.head: θεμίζω
div1.sense: to judge:—Mid., θεμισσάμενοι ὀργάς controlling our wills, Pind.

div1.head: θεμίπλεκτος
div1.sense: rightly plaited, θ. στέφανος a well-earned crown, Pind.

div1.head: θεμισκόπος
div1.sense: seeing to law and order, Pind.

div1.head: θεμισκρέων
div1.sense: reigning by right, Pind.

div1.head: θέμις
div1.sense: that which is laid down or established by custom, Lat. jus or fas, as opp. to lex, θέμις ἐστί ʼtis meet and right, Lat. fas est, Hom.; ἣ θέμις ἐστί as ʼtis right, as the custom is, Hom.; ἣ θέμις ἐστὶ γυναικός as is a womanʼs custom, Od.; so in Attic, ὅ τι θέμις αἰνεῖν what it is right to praise, Aesch., etc.:—also indeclin., θέμις being used as acc., φασὶ θέμις εἶναι Plat., etc.
= δίκη, right, law, Aesch., Soph.
pl. θέμιστες, the decrees of the Gods, oracles, Διὸς θέμιστες Od.; θέμισσιν by oracles, Pind.
rights of the chief, prerogatives, σκῆπτρόν τʼ ἠδὲ θέμιστες Il.
laws or ordinances, οἵτε θέμιστας εἰρύαται who maintain the laws, Il.
claims to be decided by the kings or judges, οἳ σκολιὰς κρίνωσι θέμιστας Il.
as prop. n., gen. Θέμιστος, Θέμιδος, Θέμιτος, voc. Θέμι, Themis, goddess of law and order, Il.

div1.head: θεμιστεῖος
div1.sense: of law and right, θ. σκᾶπτον the sceptre of righteous judgment, Pind.

div1.head: θεμιστεύω
div1.sense: to declare law and right, Lat. jus dicere, Od.: c. gen. to claim right over, to govern, Od.
to give by way of answer or oracle, Hhymn.:—absol. to deliver oracles, Eur.

div1.head: θεμιστοπόλος
div1.sense: ministering law, Hhymn.

div1.head: θεμιτός
div1.sense: like θεμιστός, allowed by the laws of God and men, righteous, Hhymn.; οὐ θεμιτόν ἐστι, like οὐ θέμις, Pind., Hdt., Attic

div1.head: θεμόω
div1.sense: to drive or bring, νῆα θέμωσε χέροον ἱκέσθαι forced, urged the ship to come to land, or simply, brought it to land, Od.

div1.head: θέναρ
div1.sense: the palm of the hand, Il.
metaph., θ. βωμοῦ the flat top of the altar, Pind.; ἁλὸς θ. the surface of the sea, Pind.

div1.head: -θεν
div1.sense: old termin. of the gen., as in ἐμέθεν, σέθεν, Διόθεν, θεόθεν; sometimes after Preps., ἀπὸ Τροίηθεν Od.; ἐξ οὐρανόθεν Il.
as insep. Particle, denoting motion from a place, opp. to -δε, as in ἄλλοθεν, οἴκοθεν, from another place, from home.

div1.head: θεοβλάβεια
div1.sense: madness, blindness, Aeschin.

div1.head: θεοβλαβέω
div1.sense: to offend the Gods, Aesch.

div1.head: θεοβλαβής
div1.sense: stricken of God, infatuated, Hdt.

div1.head: θεογεννής
div1.sense: begotten of a god, Soph.

div1.head: θεόγλωσσος
div1.sense: with the tongue of a god, Anth.

div1.head: θεογονία
div1.sense: the generation or genealogy of the gods, Hes., Hdt.

div1.head: θεόγονος
div1.sense: born of God, divine, Eur.

div1.head: θεοδήλητος
div1.sense: by which the gods are injured, Anth.

div1.head: θεοδίδακτος
div1.sense: taught of God, NTest.

div1.head: θεόδμητος
div1.sense: god-built, made or founded by the gods, Il., Pind., etc.

div1.head: θεοειδής
div1.sense: divine of form, Hom., Plat.

div1.head: θεοείκελος
div1.sense: godlike, Hom.

div1.head: θεόθεν
div1.sense: old gen. of θεός, used as adv. from the gods, at the hands of the gods, Lat. divinitus, Od.
by the help or favour of the gods, Pind., Aesch., etc.: by the gods, Soph.

div1.head: θεοίνια
div1.sense: the feast of the wine-god, ap. Dem.

div1.head: θεοκλυτέω
div1.sense: to call on the gods, Aesch.; c. acc., Eur.
c. acc. rei, to call aloud, declare, Plut.

div1.head: θεόκλυτος
div1.sense: calling on the gods, Aesch.

div1.head: θεόκραντος
div1.sense: wrought by the gods, Aesch.

div1.head: θεόκριτος
div1.sense: judging between gods, Anth.

div1.head: θεόκτιτος
div1.sense: created by God, Solon.

div1.head: θεομανής
div1.sense: maddened by the gods, Aesch., Eur.; λύσσα θ. madness caused by the gods, Eur.

div1.head: θεόμαντις
div1.sense: one who has a spirit of prophecy, an inspired person, Plat.

div1.head: θεομαχέω
div1.sense: to fight against the gods, Eur.

div1.head: θεομαχία
div1.sense: a battle of the gods, as certain books of the Il. were called, Plat.

div1.head: θεομάχος
div1.sense: fighting against God, NTest., Luc.

div1.head: θεομήστωρ
div1.sense: like the gods in counsel, Aesch.

div1.head: θεομισής
div1.sense: abominated by the gods, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: θεομορία
div1.sense: destiny, Anth.

div1.head: θεόμορος
div1.sense: destined by the gods, imparted by them, Pind.
blessed by the gods, Pind.

div1.head: θεόμορφος
div1.sense: of form divine, Anth.

div1.head: θεομυσής
div1.sense: abominated by the gods, Aesch.

div1.head: θεόπαις
div1.sense: child of the gods, Anth.

div1.head: θεόπεμπτος
div1.sense: sent by the gods, Arist.

div1.head: θεόπνευστος
div1.sense: inspired of God, NTest.

div1.head: θεοποιέω
div1.sense: to make into gods, deify, Luc.

div1.head: θεοποιός
div1.sense: making gods, Anth.

div1.head: θεοπόνητος
div1.sense: prepared by the gods, Eur.

div1.head: θεοπρεπής
div1.sense: meet for a god, Pind. adv. -πῶς, Luc.

div1.head: θεοπροπέω
div1.sense: to prophesy, only in part. masc., θεοπροπέων ἀγορεύεις Hom., Pind., etc.

div1.head: θεοπρόπιον
div1.sense: a prophecy, oracle, Il.; ἐκ θεοπροπίου according to an oracle, Hdt.

div1.head: θεοπρόπος
div1.sense: foretelling things by a spirit of prophecy, prophetic, Il., Soph.
as Subst. a seer, prophet, diviner, Hom.
a public messenger sent to enquire of the oracle, Il., Hdt., Aesch.

div1.head: θεόπτυστος
div1.sense: detested by the gods, Aesch.

div1.head: θεόπυρος
div1.sense: kindled by the gods, Eur.

div1.head: θέορτος
div1.sense: sprung from the gods, celestial, Pind., Aesch.

div1.head: θεόσδοτος
div1.sense: poet. for θεόδοτος, given by the gods, Hes., Pind.

div1.head: θεοσέβεια
div1.sense: the service or fear of God, religiousness, Xen.

div1.head: θεοσεβής
div1.sense: fearing God, religious, Hdt., Soph., etc. adv. -βῶς, Xen.

div1.head: θεόσεπτος
div1.sense: feared as divine, Ar.

div1.head: θεοσεχθρία
div1.sense: hatred of the gods, Dem.

div1.head: θεός
div1.sense: God, Hom., both in general sense, Θεὸς δώσει God will grant, and in particular sense, θεός τις a god; πατὴρ ἀνδρῶν τε θεῶν τε Hom.:—things are said to happen σὺν θεῷ, σύν γε θεοῖσιν by the will of God, Hom., etc.; οὐκ ἄνευ θεοῦ, Lat. non sine diis, Od.; οὐκ ἄνευθε θεοῦ Il.; οὐ θεῶν ἄτερ Pind.;— ἐκ θεόφι Il.;— ὑπὲρ θεόν against his will, Il.;— κατὰ θεόν τινα, Lat. divinitus, Eur.:—as an oath, πρὸς θεῶν by the gods, in Godʼs name, Trag.; θεὸς ἴστω Soph., etc.

θεός as fem. for θεά, θέαινα, a goddess, Hom.; θήλεια θεός Il.; ἡ νερτέρα θ. Proserpine, Soph.; often in oaths, νὴ τὼ θεώ Soph.; ναὶ τὼ σιώ, with the Spartans, of Castor and Pollux, Xen.; with the Boeotians, of Amphion and Zethus, Xen.
as adj. in comp. θεώτερος, more divine, θύραι θ. doors more used by the gods, Od.

div1.head: θεοστήρικτος
div1.sense: supported by God, Anth.

div1.head: θεοστυγής
div1.sense: hated of the gods, Eur.: hated of God, NTest.

div1.head: θεόσυτος
div1.sense: sent by the gods, Aesch.

div1.head: θεόταυρος
div1.sense: the god-bull, a name for Zeus, Mosch.

div1.head: θεοτείχης
div1.sense: walled by gods, of Troy, Anth.

div1.head: θεοτερπής
div1.sense: fit for the gods, Anth.

div1.head: θεότευκτος
div1.sense: made by God, Anth.

div1.head: θεότης
div1.sense: divinity, divine nature, Luc.

div1.head: θεοτίμητος
div1.sense: honoured by the gods, Tyrtae.

div1.head: θεότρεπτος
div1.sense: turned or directed by the gods, Aesch.

div1.head: θεοτρεφής
div1.sense: feeding the gods, Anth.

div1.head: θεουδής
div1.sense: fearing God, Od.

div1.head: θεοφάνια
div1.sense: sc. ἱερά a festival at Delphi, at which the statues of Apollo and other gods were shewn to the people, Hdt.

div1.head: θεοφιλής
div1.sense: dear to the gods, highly favoured, Hdt., Pind., Attic adv., θεοφιλῶς πράττειν to act as the gods will, Plat.

div1.head: θεόφιν
div1.etym: Epic gen. and dat. sg. and pl. of θεός.

div1.head: θεοφορέω
div1.sense: to bear God within one: Pass. to be possessed by a god, Luc.

div1.head: θεοφόρητος
div1.sense: possessed by a god, inspired, Aesch.

div1.head: θεοφορία
div1.sense: inspiration, Anth.

div1.head: θεόφορος
div1.sense: possessed by a god, inspired, θ. δύαι the pains of inspiration, Aesch.

div1.head: θεόφρων
div1.sense: godly-minded, Pind.

div1.head: -θε
div1.sense: inseparable suffix, v. -θεν.

div1.head: θεράπαινα
div1.sense: fem. of θεράπων, a waiting maid, handmaid, Hdt., Xen., etc.

div1.head: θεραπεία
div1.sense: a waiting on, service, θ. θεῶν service done to the gods, divine worship, Plat.
service done to gain favour, a courting, paying court, θ. τῶν ἀεὶ προεστώτων Thuc.; ἐν πολλῇ θεραπείᾳ ἔχειν to court oneʼs favour, Thuc.
of things, a fostering, tending, nurture, care, τοῦ σώματος Plat.
medical treatment, service done to the sick, tending, Thuc., Plat.
of animals or plants, a rearing or bringing up, tendance, Plat.
in collective sense, a body of attendants, suite, retinue, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: θεράπευμα
div1.sense: medical treatment, Arist.

div1.head: θεραπευτέος
div1.sense: one must do service to, τοὺς θεούς Xen.
one must cultivate, τὴν γῆν Plat.
one must cure, Plat.

div1.head: θεραπευτής
div1.sense: one who serves the gods, a worshipper, Plat.
one who serves a great man, a courtier, Xen.
one who attends to anything, c. gen., Plat.

div1.head: θεραπευτικός
div1.sense: inclined to serve a person, c. gen., Xen.: inclined to court, Plut.
absol. courteous, courtier-like, obedient, obsequious, Xen., Plut.

div1.head: θεραπευτός
div1.sense: that may be fostered, Plat.

div1.head: θεραπεύω
div1.sense: to be an attendant, do service, Od.
to do service to the gods, Lat. colere deos, Hes., Hdt., Attic:— to do service or honour to oneʼs parents or masters, Eur., Plat.
to serve, court, pay court to, τινά Hdt., Ar., etc.; and in bad sense, to flatter, wheedle, Thuc.: to conciliate, Thuc.; τὸ θεραπεῦον οἱ θεραπεύοντες, Thuc.
of things, to consult, attend to, Lat. inservire, Thuc.; ἡδονὴν θερ. to indulge oneʼs love of pleasure, Xen.; τὰς θύρας τινὸς θερ. to wait at a great manʼs door, Xen.
to take care of, provide for men, of the gods, Xen.
of things, to attend to, provide for, Soph., Thuc., etc.
θερ. τὸ σῶμα to take care of oneʼs person, Lat. cutem curare, Plat.
to treat medically, to heal, cure, Thuc., Xen.
θ. ἡμέρην to observe a day, keep it as a feast, Hdt.; θ. τὰ ἱερά Lat. sacra procurare, Thuc.
of land, to cultivate, Xen.; δένδρον θερ. to train a tree, Hdt.

div1.head: θεραπίδιον
div1.sense: a means of cure, Luc.

div1.head: θεράπνη
div1.sense: a handmaid, Hhymn., Eur.
a dwelling, abode, Eur.

div1.head: θεράπων
div1.sense: a waiting-man, attendant, Od., etc.; differing from δοῦλος, as implying free service; and in Hom. a companion in arms, though inferior in rank; as Patroclus is the companion or esquire of Achilles; Meriones of Idomeneus, Il.; so the charioteer is ἡνίοχος θεράπων; kings were Διὸς θεράποντες; warriors θεράποντες Ἄρηος, etc.:—c. dat., οἶκος ξένοισι θεράπων devoted to the service of its guests, Pind.
later, simply, a servant, Hdt.:—in Chios, θεράποντες was the name for their slaves, Thuc.

div1.head: θέραψ
div1.sense: rare poet. form for θεράπων: nom. pl. θέραπες Eur., Anth.

div1.head: θέρειος
div1.sense: of summer, in summer:— θερεία, Ionic -είη, (sc. ὥρα) , = θέρος, summer-time, summer, Hdt.; ταῖς θερείαις Pind.

div1.head: θερίζω
div1.sense: to do summer-work, to mow, reap, σῖτον, κριθάς, καρπόν Hdt., Ar., etc.:—Mid., καρπὸν Δηοῦς θερίσασθαι Ar.
metaph. to cut off, Soph., Eur.
metaph. to reap a good harvest, Ar.
ὁ θερίζων (with or without λόγος) a kind of syllogism, Luc.
intr. to pass the summer, Xen.; cf. ἐαρίζω, χειμάζω.

div1.head: θερισμός
div1.sense: reaping-time, harvest, NTest.
the harvest, crop, NTest.

div1.head: θεριστής
div1.sense: a reaper, harvester, Eur., Xen.

div1.head: θερίστριον
div1.sense: a light summer garment, opp. to χειμάστριον, Theocr., so θέριστρον, ου, τό, Anth.

div1.head: θερμαίνω
div1.sense: to warm, heat, Il., Aesch., etc.:—Pass. to be heated, grow hot, Od.

metaph. to heat, ἕως ἐθέρμηνʼ αὐτὸν φλὸξ οἴνου Eur.; σπλάγχνα θ. Ar.; πολλὰ θ. φρενί to cherish hot feelings, Aesch.:—Pass., θερμαίνεσθαι ἐλπίσι to glow with hope, Soph.; χαρᾶι θ. καρδίαν to have oneʼs heart warm with joy, Eur.

div1.head: θέρμη
div1.sense: heat, feverish heat, Thuc., etc.

div1.head: θέρμινος
div1.sense: of lupines (θέρμος) , Luc.

div1.head: θερμοβαφής
div1.sense: dyed hot, opp. to ψυχροβαφής, Theophr.

div1.head: θερμόβλυστος
div1.sense: hot-bubbling, Paul_s_therm.

div1.head: θερμόβουλος
div1.sense: hot-tempered, Eur. ap. Ar.

div1.head: θερμοδότης
div1.sense: one who brought the hot water at baths, Lat. caldarius; fem. θερμοδότις, ιδος, Anth.

div1.head: θερμόνους
div1.sense: heated in mind, Aesch.

div1.head: Θερμοπύλαι
div1.sense: literally hot-gates, i. e. a narrow gate-like pass, in which were hot springs, name of the famous pass from Thessaly to Locris, the key of Greece, also called simply Πύλαι, Hdt.

div1.head: θερμός
div1.sense: hot, warm, θερμὰ λοετρά Hom.; of tears, Hom., etc.
metaph. hot, hasty, rash, headlong, like Lat. calidus, Aesch., Ar., etc.
still warm, fresh, ἴχνη Anth.
τὸ θερμόν θερμότης, heat, Lat. calor, Hdt., Plat., etc.
θερμόν (sc. ὕδωρ) , hot water, θερμῷ λοῦσθαι Ar.
τὰ θερμά (sub. χωρία) , Hdt.: but (sub. λουτρά) , hot baths, Xen.
adv. -μῶς, Plat.

div1.head: θέρμος
div1.sense: a lupine, Anth.

div1.head: θερμότης
div1.sense: heat, Lat. calor, Plat.

div1.head: θερμουργός
div1.sense: doing hot and hasty acts, reckless, Xen., Luc.

div1.head: θέρμω
div1.sense: to heat, make hot, Od., Ar.:—Pass. to be heated, grow hot, Hom.

div1.head: θέρος
div1.sense: summer, summertime, χείματος οὐδὲ θέρευς in winter nor in summer, Od.; οὔτʼ ἐν θέρει οὔτʼ ἐν ὀπώρῃ Od.; τὸ θέρος during the summer, Hdt.; θέρους μεσοῦντος about mid summer, Luc.
summer-fruits, harvest, a crop, Aesch., Ar., etc.; metaph., δράκοντος θ. Eur.

div1.head: Θερσίτης
div1.sense: Thersites, i. e. the audacious ( from θέρσος, Aeolic for θάρσος) , Hom.

div1.head: θέρω
div1.sense: Pass. to become hot or warm, warm oneself, Od.; πυρός at the fire, Od.; θέρου warm yourself, Ar.
of things, μὴ ἄστυ πυρὸς θέρηται lest the city be burnt by fire, Il.

div1.head: θέσις
div1.sense: a setting, placing, arranging, Pind., Plat.; θ. νόμων lawgiving, Dem.
a deposit of money, preparatory to a law-suit, Ar.: money paid in advance, earnest-money, Dem.
position, situation, Lat. situs, of a city, Thuc., etc.

div1.head: θέσκελος
div1.sense: marvellous, wondrous, θέσκελα ἔργα works of wonder, Hom.:—as adv., ἔϊκτο δὲ θέσκελον αὐτῷ ʼtwas wondrous like him, Il.

div1.head: θέσμιος
div1.sense: according to law, lawful, Pind., Aesch.
θέσμια, τά, as Subst., laws, customs, rites, Hdt., etc.; also in sg., Eur.

div1.head: θεσμοθετέω
div1.sense: to be a θεσμοθέτης, Dem.

div1.head: θεσμοθέτης
div1.sense: a lawgiver:—at Athens, the θεσμοθέται were the six junior archons, who judged causes assigned to no special court, Aeschin., etc.

div1.head: θεσμοποιέω
div1.sense: to make laws, Eur.

div1.head: θεσμός
div1.sense: like θέμις, that which is laid down and established, a law, ordinance, Lat. institutum, λέκτροιο θεσμὸν ἵκοντο, i. e. they fulfilled the established law of wedlock, Od.; so in Hdt. and Attic
at Athens, Dracoʼs laws were called θεσμοί, because each began with the word θεσμός (cf. θεσμοθέτης) , while Solon.ʼs laws were named νόμοι.
an institution, ordinance, as the court of Areopagus, Aesch.; of the great games, Pind.

div1.head: θεσμοσύνη
div1.sense: justice, like δικαιοσύνη, Anth.

div1.head: θεσμοφοριάζω
div1.sense: to keep the Thesmophoria, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: θεσμοφόρια
div1.sense: the Thesmophoria, an ancient festival held by the Athenian women in honour of Demeter Θεσμοφόρος, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: θεσμοφόριον
div1.sense: the temple of Demeter Θεσμοφόρος, Ar.

div1.head: θεσμοφόρος
div1.sense: law-giving, an ancient name of Demeter (Ceres), Hdt.; τὼ θεσμοφόρω Ceres and Proserpine, Ar.

div1.head: θεσμοφύλαξ
div1.sense: guardian of the law, Thuc.

div1.head: θεσπέσιος
div1.sense: properly of the voice, divinely sounding, divinely sweet, Hom., Pind.
that can be spoken by none but God, i. e. unspeakable, ineffable; hence,
like θεῖος, divine, Hom.; dat. fem. θεσπεσίῃ (sc. βουλῇ) by the will of God, Hom.; θ. ὁδός the way of divination, of Cassandra, Aesch.

wondrous, marvellous, portentous, awful, of things, Hom.; θ. χαλκός marvellous fine brass, Od., Il.; θ. ὀδμή a smell divinely sweet, Od.; so in Hdt., θεσπέσιον ὡς ἡδύ:—of human affairs, θ. φόβος Il., etc.
adv. -ίως, θ. ἐφόβηθεν they trembled unspeakably, Il.: so neut. as adv., Theocr.

div1.head: θεσπιδαής
div1.sense: kindled by a god, θ. πῦρ furious, portentous fire, such as seems more than natural, Hom.

div1.head: θεσπιέπεια
div1.sense: fem. adj. oracular, prophetic, Soph.

div1.head: θεσπίζω
div1.etym: Ionic inf. θεσπιέειν Hdt.; Doric aor1 ἐθέσπιξα
div1.sense: to declare by oracle, prophesy, divine, Hdt., Trag.; Pass., τί δὲ τεθέσπισται; Soph.

div1.head: θέσπισμα
div1.sense: in pl., oracular sayings, Hdt., Soph.

div1.head: θέσπις
div1.sense: having words from God, inspired, Od., Eur.
generally, divine, wondrous, awful, θέσπις ἄελλα Hhymn.

div1.head: θεσπιῳδέω
div1.sense: to prophesy, sing in prophetic strain, Aesch., Eur., Ar.

div1.head: θεσπιῳδός
div1.sense: singing in prophetic strain, prophetic, Eur.
caused by prophecy, φόβος Aesch.

div1.head: Θεσσαλός
div1.sense: a Thessalian, Hdt., etc.; proverb., Θεσσαλὸν σόφισμα a Thessalian trick, from the faithless character of the people, Eur.
Θεσσαλὶς κυνῆ a Thessalian cap, Soph.

div1.head: θέσσασθαι
div1.sense: to pray, Pind.

div1.head: θεσφατηλόγος
div1.sense: prophetic, Aesch.

div1.head: θέσφατος
div1.sense: spoken by God, decreed, ordained, appointed, Lat. fatalis, Aesch., Soph.: θέσφατόν ἐστι it is ordained, Il.; σοὶ δʼ οὐ θ. ἐστι θανέειν ʼtis not appointed thee to die, Od.
as Subst., θέσφατα, τά, divine decrees, oracles, Od., Trag., etc.
generally, like θεῖος, divine, Od.

div1.head: θετέος
div1.sense: to be laid down, Arist.
θετέον, one must lay down, Xen.

div1.head: Θετίδειον
div1.sense: the temple of Thetis, Eur.

div1.head: θετικός
div1.sense: of or for adoption, Arist.

div1.head: Θέτις
div1.sense: Thetis, one of the Nereids, wife of Peleus, mother of Achilles
div1.etym: Hom. uses Θέτῑ for dat. and vocat.; Θέτιν for acc.

div1.head: θετός
div1.sense: taken as oneʼs child, adopted, Pind., Hdt., etc.

div1.head: θέω
div1.etym: the syllables εο, εου remain uncontracted even in Attic
the tenses other than present θέω and future θεύσομαι are supplied by τρέχω and *δρέμω
div1.sense: to run, Hom., etc.; θέειν πεδίοιο to run over the plain, Il.: in part. with another Verb, ἦλθε θέων, ἦλθε θέουσα came running, Il.; θέων Αἴαντα κάλεσσον run and call him, Il.
περὶ τρίποδος θεύσεσθαι to run for a tripod, Il.; περὶ ψυχῆς θέον Ἕκτορος they were running for Hectorʼs life, Il.
of other kinds of motion, as,
of birds, θεύσονται δρόμωι Ar.
of ships, ἔθεε κατὰ κῦμα Il.; of a potterʼs wheel, Il.; of a quoit, ῥίμφα θέων ἀπὸ χειρός flying lightly, Od.

of things which (as we say) run in a continuous line, though not actually in motion, φλὲψ ἀνὰ νῶτα θέουσα Il.; esp. of anything circular, which runs round into itself, ἄντυξ, ἣ πυμάτη θέεν ἀσπίδος Il.
c. acc. loci, to run over, τὰ ὄρη Xen.

div1.head: θεωρέω
div1.sense: to look at, view, behold, Hdt., Aesch., etc.: to inspect or review soldiers, Xen.
of the mind, to contemplate, consider, observe, Plat., etc.
to view the public games, of spectators, θ. τὰ Ὀλύμπια Hdt., etc.; θ. τινά to see him act, Dem.: —absol. to go as a spectator, ἐς τὰ Ἐφέσια Thuc.
to be a θεωρός or state-ambassador to the oracle or at the games, Ar., Thuc.
in θεωρήσασα τοὐμὸν ὄμμα Soph., the acc. ὄμμα may be taken as in βαίνειν πόδα, having beheld with mine eye.

div1.head: θεώρημα
div1.sense: that which is looked at, viewed, a sight, spectacle, Dem., etc.
a principle thereby arrived at, a rule, Lat. praeceptum: in Mathematics, a theorem, Euclid.

div1.head: θεωρητήριον
div1.sense: a seat in a theatre, Plut.

div1.head: θεωρητικός
div1.sense: fond of contemplating a thing, c. gen., Arist.: absol. speculative, Arist., Plut., etc.

div1.head: θεωρία
div1.sense: a looking at, viewing, beholding, θεωρίης εἵνεκεν ἐκδημεῖν to go abroad to see the world, Hdt.; so Thuc., etc.: of the mind, contemplation, speculation, Plat., etc.
pass. = θεώρημα, a sight, show, spectacle, Aesch., Eur., etc.; esp. at a theatre, Ar., Xen.
the being a spectator at the theatre or the public games, Soph., Plat.
the θεωροί or state-ambassadors sentto the office of θεωρός, a mission, Plat., Xen.
the office of θεωρός, discharge of that office, Thuc., etc.

div1.head: θεωρικός
div1.sense: of or for θεωρία (signfs. II and III), πεπλώματʼ οὐ θεωρικά no festal robes, Eur.

θεωρικά (sc. χρήματα) , τά, the money, which, from the time of Pericles, was given to the poor citizens to pay for seats in the theatre (at 2 obols the seat), but also for other purposes, Dem.: in sg., τὸ θεωρικόν the theatric fund, Dem.

div1.head: θεωρίς
div1.sense: a sacred ship, which carried the θεωροί (cf. θεωρός II) to their destination, but was also used for other state-purposes, Hdt., Plat.: metaph. of Charonʼs bark, Aesch.
(sub. ὁδός) the road by which the θεωροί went.

div1.head: θεωρός
div1.sense: a spectator, Theogn., Aesch., etc.; θ. εἰκάδων viewing the festivals or present at them, Eur.

an ambassador sent to consult an oracle or to present an offering, Soph., ap. Dem. The Athenians sent θεωροί to Delphi, to Delos, and to the four great games, the Olympian, Pythian, Nemean and Isthmian.
div1.etym: Derived in first sense from θεάομαι; in second perh. from θεός, ὤρα, cura.

div1.head: θεώτερος
div1.sense: more divine: v. θεός.

div1.head: Θηβαγενής
div1.sense: sprung from Thebes, Theban, Hes.

div1.head: Θηβαιεύς
div1.sense: epith. of Zeus, the Theban, Hdt.

div1.head: Θηβαῖος
div1.sense: Theban, Hom., etc.; Θηβαϊκός, ή, όν, Hdt.

div1.head: Θῆβαι
div1.sense: Thebes, the name of several cities, the most famous being the Egyptian (ἑκατόμπυλοι) , and the Boeotian (ἑπτάπυλοι) , Hom.

div1.head: Θηβαΐς
div1.sense: the Thebais, i. e. territory of Thebes (in Egypt), Hdt.; (in Boeotia), Thuc.

div1.head: Θήβασδε
div1.sense: to Thebes, Il.

div1.head: Θήβηθεν
div1.sense: from Thebes, Anth.; Aeolic Θείβᾱθεν, Ar.

div1.head: Θήβησιν
div1.sense: at Thebes, Hom.; Aeolic Θείβᾱθι, Ar.

div1.head: θηγαλέος
div1.sense: pointed, sharp, Anth.
act. sharpening, c. gen., Anth.

div1.head: θηγάνη
div1.sense: a whetstone, Aesch., Soph.: metaph., αἱματηραὶς θηγάναι incentives to bloodshed, Aesch.

div1.head: θήγω
div1.sense: to sharpen, whet, Il.; θήγων λευκὸν ὀδόντα Il.; θ. φάσγανον, ξίφος Aesch., Eur.:—in Mid., δόρυ θηξάσθω let him whet his spear, Il.
metaph. to sharpen, excite, provoke, like Lat. acuere, τὰς ψυχὰς εἰς τὰ πολεμικά Xen.:—Pass., λόγοι τεθηγμένοι sharp, biting words, Aesch.; γλῶσσα τεθηγμένη Soph.

div1.head: θηητήρ
div1.sense: one who gazes at, an admirer, Od.

div1.head: θηητός
div1.sense: gazed at, wondrous, admirable, Lat. spectandus, Hes., Pind.

div1.head: θήϊον
div1.sense: Epic for θεῖον, brimstone, Od.

div1.head: θηκαῖος
div1.sense: like a chest or coffin, οἴκημα θ. a burial vault, Hdt.

div1.head: θήκη
div1.sense: a case to put anything in, a box, chest, Hdt., Eur.
a place for corpses, a grave, tomb, Hdt., Aesch.
a mode of burial, Thuc.

div1.head: θηκτός
div1.sense: sharpened, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: θηλάζω
div1.sense: of the mother, to suckle, Lat. lactare, Lys., NTest.
of the young animal, to suck, Lat. lactere; θηλάζων χοῖρος a sucking pig, Theocr.: c. acc., μασδὸν ἐθήλαξεν Theocr.

div1.head: θηλασμός
div1.sense: a giving suck, suckling, Plut.

div1.head: θηλέω
div1.sense: to be full of, c. gen., λειμῶνες ἴου ἠδὲ σελίνου θήλεον the meadows were full of violets and parsley, Od.; so c. dat., θάλησε σελίνοις Pind.
absol. to flourish, Anth.

div1.head: θηλή
div1.sense: the part of the breast which gives suck, the teat, nipple, Eur., Plat.

div1.head: θηλυγενής
div1.sense: of female sex, womanish, Eur.

div1.head: θηλύγλωσσος
div1.sense: with womanʼs tongue, Anth.

div1.head: θηλυδρίας
div1.sense: a womanish, effeminate person, Hdt., Luc.

div1.head: θηλυκρατής
div1.sense: swaying women, Aesch.

div1.head: θηλυκτόνος
div1.sense: slaying by womanʼs hand, Aesch.

div1.head: θηλυμελής
div1.sense: singing in soft strain, Anth.

div1.head: θηλυμίτρης
div1.sense: with a womanʼs head-band, Luc.: fem. θηλυμίτρις, ιδος, Luc.

div1.head: θηλύμορφος
div1.sense: woman-shaped, Eur.

div1.head: θηλύνοος
div1.sense: of womanish mind, Aesch.

div1.head: θηλύνω
div1.sense: to make womanish, to enervate, Eur., Xen.: metaph. to soften, Ζέφυρος κῦμα θηλύνει Anth.:—Pass. to become weak and womanish, Soph.: to play the coquet. Bion.

div1.head: θηλυπρεπής
div1.sense: befitting a woman, Anth.

div1.head: θηλύσπορος
div1.sense: of female kind, Aesch.

div1.head: θῆλυς
div1.sense: of female sex, female, θήλεια θεός a goddess, Il.; θήλειαι ἵπποι mares, Od.; σύες θήλειαι sows, Od.; ὄϊς θῆλυς a ewe, Il.; ἄπαις θήλεος γόνου without female issue, Hdt.:— ἡ θήλεα, Attic -εια, the female, Hdt., Aesch.; χρῆμα θηλειῶν woman-kind, Eur.; τὸ θῆλυ γένος or τὸ θῆλυ the female sex, woman kind, Eur.
of or belonging to women, Hdt., Aesch.; θ. φόνος murder by women, Eur.
in Gramm. feminine.
applied to persons and things,
fresh, refreshing, of dew, Hes.

tender, delicate, gentle, θηλύτεραι γυναῖκες, θηλύτεραι θεαί (where the comp. is used much like a Positive), Hom.; θῆλυς ἀπὸ χροιᾶς delicate of skin, Theocr.; of character, soft, yielding, weak, γυνὴ θῆλυς οὖσα Soph.

div1.head: θηλύτης
div1.sense: womanishness, delicacy, effeminacy, Plut.

div1.head: θηλυτόκος
div1.sense: giving birth to girls, Theocr.

div1.head: θηλυφανής
div1.sense: like a woman, Plut., Anth.

div1.head: θηλυχίτων
div1.sense: with womanʼs frock, Anth., Luc.

div1.head: θημολογέω
div1.sense: to collect in a heap, shortened from θημωνολογέω, Anth.

div1.head: θημών
div1.sense: a heap, Od.

div1.head: θην
div1.sense: enclitic Particle, chiefly Epic, = δή, expressing strong conviction, surely now, Hom., Theocr.; ironically, λείψετέ θην νέας so then you will leave the ships, Il.; strengthd, ἦ θην in very truth, Il.; οὔ θην surely not, Hom.

div1.head: θηραγρέτης
div1.sense: a hunter, Eur., Anth.

div1.head: θήραμα
div1.sense: that which is caught, prey, spoil, booty, Eur., Anth.

div1.head: θήρα
div1.sense: a hunting of wild beasts, the chase, Hom., Hdt., etc.
metaph. eager pursuit of anything, Soph.
the beast taken, spoil, booty, prey, game, Od., Aesch., etc; in pl., ὦ πταναὶ θῆραι, of birds, Soph.

div1.head: θηράσιμος
div1.sense: to be hunted down or caught, Aesch.

div1.head: θηρατέος
div1.sense: to be hunted after, sought eagerly, Soph., Xen.
θηρατέον one must hunt after, Xen.

div1.head: θηρατήρ
div1.sense: a hunter, Il.

div1.head: θηρατής
div1.sense: one who hunts for words, Ar.

div1.head: θηρατικός
div1.etym: = θηρευτικός: metaph., τὰ θ. τῶν φίλων
div1.sense: the arts for winning friends, Xen.

div1.head: θήρατρον
div1.sense: an instrument of the chase, a net, trap, Xen.

div1.head: θηράω
div1.sense: to hunt or chase wild beasts, Soph., Xen.:—of men, to catch, capture, Xen.: metaph. to captivate, Xen.:— θ. πόλιν to seek to destroy it, Aesch.
metaph., like Lat. venari, to hunt after a thing, pursue it eagerly, Trag.:—c. inf. to seek or endeavour to do, Eur.; and in Mid., Soph., Eur.
Mid. much like Act. to hunt for, fish for, ἐγχέλεις Ar.; absol., οἱ θηρώμενοι hunters, Xen.
metaph. to cast about for, seek after, Hdt., Eur., etc.
Pass. to be hunted, pursued, Aesch., etc.

div1.head: θήρειος
div1.sense: of wild beasts, Lat. feri_nus, θήρειον γραφήν the figures of animals worked upon the cloak, Aesch.; θ. δάκος θήρ, Eur.; θ. βία, periphr. for ὁ θήρ, the centaur, Soph.; θ. κρέα game, Xen.

div1.head: θήρευμα
div1.sense: spoil, prey, Eur.

div1.head: θήρευσις
div1.sense: hunting, the chase, Plat.

div1.head: θηρευτής
div1.sense: a hunter, huntsman, Il.; κυσὶ θηρευτῇσι Il.; also of a fisher, Hdt.

div1.head: θηρευτικός
div1.sense: of or for hunting, κύνες θ. hounds, Ar., Xen.; βίος θ. the life of hunters, Arist.

div1.head: θηρεύω
div1.sense: to hunt, go hunting, Od., Hdt.
c. acc. to hunt after, chase, catch, Hdt., Xen., etc.:—of men, to hunt down, Hdt.; to lay wait for, Xen.:—Pass. to be hunted, Hdt.: to be caught, Aesch.
metaph. to hunt after, Aesch., Eur., etc.

div1.head: θηρίον
div1.etym: in form a Dim. of θήρ, but in usage equiv. to it.
div1.sense: a wild animal, beast, of a stag, Od.;—of savage beasts, Hdt., Xen., etc.; but, of a pig, Plat.; of a dog, Theocr.:—in pl. beasts, opp. to men, birds, and fishes, wild animals, game, Hdt., Plat.:—proverb., ἢ θηρίον ἢ θεός, i. e. either below or above the nature of man, Arist.
an animal, Hdt., Plat.
a poisonous animal, reptile, serpent, NTest.
also as real Dim. a little animal, insect, of bees, Theocr.
as a term of reproach, beast! like Lat. bellua, French bete, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: θηριότης
div1.sense: the nature of a beast, brutality, Arist.

trans.i: to make into a wild beast.

div1.head: θηριώδης
div1.sense: full of wild beasts, infested by them, Lat. belluosus, of countries, Hdt.
of men, beast-like, wild, savage, brutal, Lat. bellui_nus, Eur., Plat., etc.:— τὸ θ. the animal nature, Eur.

div1.head: θηρίωσις
div1.sense: a turning into a beast, Luc.

div1.head: θηροβολέω
div1.sense: to slay wild beasts, Soph.

div1.head: θηρόβοτος
div1.sense: where wild beasts feed, Anth.

div1.head: θηρόθυμος
div1.sense: with brutal mind, brutal, Anth.

div1.head: θηροκτόνος
div1.sense: killing wild beasts, ἐν φοναῖς θηροκτόνοις, i. e. in the chase, Eur.

div1.head: θηρολέτης
div1.sense: slayer of beasts, Anth.

div1.head: θηρόλετος
div1.sense: slain by beasts, Anth.

div1.head: θηρομιγής
div1.sense: half-beast, θηρ. τις ὠρυγή a cry as of beasts, Plut.

div1.head: θηρονόμος
div1.sense: tending wild beasts, Anth.

div1.head: θηροσκόπος
div1.sense: looking out for wild beasts, Hhymn.

div1.head: θηροσύνη
div1.sense: the chase, Anth.

div1.head: θηροτόκος
div1.sense: producing beasts, ἄλση Anth.

div1.head: θηροτρόφος
div1.sense: feeding wild beasts, Eur.

div1.head: θηρότροφος
div1.sense: proparox. θηρότροφος, feeding on beasts, Eur.

div1.head: θηροφόνος
div1.sense: killing wild beasts, Eur.

div1.head: θήρ
div1.sense: a wild beast, beast of prey, Il., etc.; joined with λέων, Eur.; with λέαινα, Anth.; also of Cerberus, Soph.:—in pl. beasts, as opp. to birds and fishes, Od., etc.
of any animal, as of birds, Ar., etc.
any fabulous monster, as the sphinx, Aesch.; esp. a centaur, Soph. (cf. Φήρ) ; a satyr, Eur.

div1.head: θησαυρίζω
div1.sense: to store or treasure up, Hdt., Xen., etc.

div1.head: θησαύρισμα
div1.sense: a store, treasure, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: θησαυρισμός
div1.sense: a laying up in store, Arist.

div1.head: θησαυροποιός
div1.sense: laying up in store, Plat.

div1.head: θησαυρός
div1.sense: a store laid up, treasure, Aesch., Ar.:—metaph., θ. ὕμνων Pind.; Διὸς θ., of fire, Eur.; οἰωνοῖς γλυκὺς θ., of a dead body, Soph.
a store-house, treasure-house, magazine, Hdt.: the treasury of a temple, Hdt., Xen.
any receptacle for valuables, a chest, casket, Hdt.; θ. βελέεσσιν, of a quiver, Aesch.

div1.head: Θησεῖδαι
div1.sense: sons to Theseus, i. e. the Athenians, Soph.

div1.head: Θησεῖον
div1.sense: the temple of Theseus, a sanctuary for criminals and runaway slaves, Ar.
τὰ Θησεῖα, ( sc. ἱερά) the festival of Theseus, Ar.

div1.head: Θησεύς
div1.sense: Theseus, the famous ancestral hero of Athens, Il., etc.
div1.etym: From !θε, Root of τίθημι, the settler; cf. θής.

div1.head: Θησηΐς
div1.sense: of Theseus, Aesch.
as Subst. the Theseid, a poem on Theseus, Arist.
name of a mode of haircutting, first used by Theseus, Plut.

div1.head: θής
div1.sense: a serf or villain, bound to till his lordʼs land, Lat. ascriptus glebae, opp. to a mere slave, θῆτές τε δμῶές τε Od.: also a hired farm-servant or bailiff, Lat. villicus, Hes., Plat.

at Athens, by the constitution of Solon., the θῆτες were the fourth class, (the other three being πεντακοσιομέδιμνοι, ἱππεῖς, ζευγίται) , including all whose property in land was under 150 medimni, Plut.: they were employed as light-armed and seamen.
div1.etym: From !θε, Root of τίθημι, a settler.

div1.head: θῆσσα
div1.sense: a poor girl, one obliged to go out for hire, Plut.fem. of θής, q. v.
as adj. θῆσσα τράπεζα menial fare, Eur.
div1.etym: From !θε, Root of τίθημι, a settler.

div1.head: θῆσσα
div1.sense: Greek form of Lat. thensa, a sacred car, Plut.

div1.head: θῆτα
div1.sense: Θ, θ, θῆτα, τό, indecl., eighth letter of the Gr. alphabet: as numeral θ ἐννέα, ἔνατος, but θ 90000. —q is the aspirated dental mute, related to the tenuis τ and the medial δ. θ is sometimes represented by φ, as θλάω φλάω; so in Lat. θήρ (Aeolic φήρ) fera; θύρα fores; byβ, as ἐ-ρυθρός ruber, οὖθαρ uber.
changes of θ in the Gr. dialects:
Lacon., into ς, as σάλασσα σεῖος Ἀσάνα παρσένος for θάλασσα θεῖος Ἀθάνα παρθένος.
Aeolic and Doric into τ, as αὖτις ἐντεῦθεν for αὖθις ἐντεῦθεν.
when θ was repeated in two foll. syllables, the former became τ, as Ἀτθίς.

div1.head: θητεία
div1.sense: hired service, service, Soph.

div1.head: θητεύω
div1.sense: to be a serf or menial, serve for hire, Hom., Hdt., Attic

div1.head: θητικός
div1.sense: of or for a hireling, menial, Arist.
τὸ θητικόν, the class of θῆτες, Arist.

div1.head: θιασάρχης
div1.sense: the leader of a θίασος, Luc.

div1.head: θιασεύω
div1.sense: to bring into the Bacchic company, Eur.:— Pass. to be of the Bacchic company, to be hallowed by Bacchic rites, Eur.

div1.head: θίασος
div1.sense: a band or company marching through the streets with dance and song, esp. in honour of Bacchus, a band of revellers, Hdt., Eur., etc.
generally, any party, company, troop, Eur., Xen.

div1.head: θιασώτης
div1.sense: the member of a θίασος, Ar., etc.:— c. gen., θιασῶται τοῦ Ἔρωτος followers of Love, Xen.; ὁ ἐμὸς θ. Eur.
of Bacchus, leader of θίασοι, Anth.

div1.head: θιγγάνω
div1.sense: to touch, handle, c. gen., Trag.
to take hold of, τινός Soph., etc.; ὠλέναις θ. τινός to embrace, Eur.
to touch, attempt, λόγου γλώσσηι θ. Soph.:—in hostile sense, to attack, θηρός Eur.
metaph. of the feelings, to touch, Eur.; ψυχῆς, φρενῶν θ. Eur.; πολλὰ θιγγάνει πρὸς ἧπαρ reach to the heart, Aesch.
to reach, gain, win, τινός Pind., etc.:—Pind. uses it in this sense, as he does ψαύω, c. dat.

div1.head: θι
div1.sense: originally a termin. of the gen., as in Ἰλιόθι πρό, ἠῶθι πρό Il.
insepar. Affix of several Substs., Adjs., and Pronouns, to which it gives an adv. sense, denoting the place at which, οἴκοθι, ἄλλοθι, etc.

div1.head: θίς
div1.sense: a heap, Od., Aesch.:—in pl. sand-heaps, sand-bank, Hdt., etc.
the beach, shore, παρὰ θῖνα θαλάσσης Il.; παρὰ θῖνʼ ἁλός Il.; so, ἐπὶ θινί Od.
sand or mud at the bottom of the sea, οἶδμα κυλίνδει βυσσόθεν θῖνα Soph.; metaph., τὸν θῖνά μου ταράττεις you trouble the very bottom of my heart, Ar.

div1.head: θλάω
div1.sense: to crush, bruise, Hom.

div1.head: θλίβω
div1.sense: to press, squeeze, pinch, Ar., Dem.:—Pass. of a person heavy-laden, ὡς θλίβομαι! Ar.:—Mid., πολλῆισι φλιῆισι θλίψεται ὤμους he will rub his shoulders against many doorposts, of a beggar, Od.
to pinch, compress, straiten, Plat.:—Pass. to be compressed, θλιβομένα καλύβα a small, close hut, Theocr.; ὁδὸς τεθλιμμένη a narrow way, NTest.
metaph. to oppress, afflict, distress, Arist.

div1.head: θνῄσκω
div1.etym: The Root is !θαν, found in aor2 θανεῖν, etc.
The form τεθνειώς appears as a variant reading at Iliad 17.161
div1.sense: to die, be dying, in aor2 and perf. to be dead, Hom., etc.; the pres. sometimes takes a perf. sense, θνήσκουσι γάρ, for τεθνήκασι, Soph., Eur.

often used like a pass. Verb, χερσὶν ὑπʼ Αἴαντος θανέειν to fall by his hand, be slain by him, Il., etc.:—note the phrase of Dem., τεθνᾶσι τῶι δέει τοὺς τοιούτους, where τεθνᾶσι τῶι δέει must be taken as a single Verb, are in mortal fear of.
metaph. of things, to die, perish, Aesch., Soph., etc.

div1.head: θνητογενής
div1.sense: of mortal race, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: θνητοειδής
div1.sense: of mortal nature, Plat.

div1.head: θνητός
div1.sense: liable to death, mortal, Hom., etc.:—as Subst., θνητοί mortals, Od., Trag.
of things, befitting mortals, human, Pind., Eur., etc.

div1.head: θοάζω
div1.sense: trans. to move quickly, ply rapidly, πτέρυγας Eur.; τίς ὅδʼ ἀγὼν θοάζων σε; what task is thus hurrying thee on? Eur.; θοάζω πόνον I urge it on, Eur.; θ. σῖτα to dispatch food quickly, Eur.
intr. to move quickly, hurry along, rush, dart, Eur.
= θάσσω, to sit, τίνας ποθʼ ἕδρας θοάζετε; why sit ye in this suppliant posture? Soph.

div1.head: θοίναμα
div1.sense: a meal, feast, Eur.

div1.head: θοινατήρ
div1.sense: lord of the feast, Aesch.

div1.head: θοινατικός
div1.sense: of or for a feast, Xen.

div1.head: θοινάω
div1.sense: to feast on, eat, ἰχθῦς Hes.
to feast, entertain, φίλους Eur.; τὸ δεῖπνον, τό μιν ἐκεῖνος ἐθοίνησε the feast, which he gave him, Hdt.
Mid. and Pass., fut. ήσομαι and άσομαι [ᾱ]: aor1 ἐθοινήθην and -ησάμην· perf. τεθοίνᾱμαι:— absol. to be feasted, to feast, banquet, Hom., Od., Eur.:—c. acc. to feast on, Eur.; so c. gen., Anth.

div1.head: θοίνη
div1.sense: a meal, feast, banquet, dinner, Hes., Hdt., Attic

div1.head: θολερός
div1.sense: muddy, foul, thick, troubled, Lat. turbidus, properly of water, Hdt., Thuc., etc.
metaph. troubled by passion or madness, θολεροὶ λόγοι Aesch.; θολερῷ χειμῶνι with turbid storm of madness, Soph.

div1.head: θολία
div1.sense: a conical hat with a broad brim to keep the sun off, Theocr.

div1.head: θόλος
div1.sense: a round building with a conical roof, a vaulted chamber, Od.
at Athens, the Rotunda, in which the Prytanes dined, Plat., etc.

div1.head: θολός
div1.sense: mud, dirt, esp. the thick, dark juice of the cuttle-fish (sepia), which it emits to trouble the water and hide himself, Lat. loligo, Arist.

div1.head: θολόω
div1.sense: to make turbid, properly of water: metaph., θ. καρδίαν Eur.

div1.head: θοός
div1.sense: quick, nimble, active, Il.; θοὴ νύξ swift Night, because she drove a car, or came on suddenly, Hom.; θοὴν ἀλεγύνετε δαῖτα prepare a hasty meal, Od., etc.:—adv. θοῶς, quickly, in haste, Hom.; soon, Od.
of the Echinades, islands with sharp-peaks, Od.

div1.head: θοόω
div1.sense: to make sharp or pointed, Od.

div1.head: Θορικόνδε
div1.sense: to Thoricus, Hhymn.

div1.head: θόρνυμαι
div1.sense: Dep., = θρώσκω II, 3rd pl. subj. θορνύωνται Hdt.

div1.head: θορός
div1.sense: semen genitale, Hdt.

div1.head: θορυβάζομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be troubled, NTest.

div1.head: θορυβέω
div1.sense: to make a noise or uproar, of a crowd, Ar.
like Lat. acclamare, to shout in token either of approbation or the contrary:
to cheer, applaud, Plat.
to raise clamours against, c. dat., Thuc., Plat., etc.:—Pass. to have clamours raised against one, Soph.
trans. to confuse by noise or tumult, to trouble, throw into confusion, Thuc.:—Pass. to be thrown into confusion, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: θορυβητικός
div1.sense: uproarious, turbulent, Ar.

div1.head: θορυβοποιός
div1.sense: making an uproar, Plut.

div1.head: θόρυβος
div1.sense: a noise, uproar, clamour, Pind., Eur., Thuc., etc.; θόρυβος βοῆς a confused clamour, Soph.
in token of approbation or the contrary:
applause, cheers, Ar., Plat., etc.
groans, murmurs, Soph.
tumult, confusion, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: θορυβώδης
div1.sense: noisy, uproarious, turbulent, Plat.
causing alarm, Xen.

div1.head: Θουριόμαντις
div1.sense: a Thurian prophet, of Lampon who led the colony to Thurium, Ar.

div1.head: θούριος
div1.etym: in Attic Poets for θοῦρος, Aesch., etc.

div1.head: θοῦρις
div1.sense: θοῦρις ἀσπίς, the shield with which one rushes to the fight, Il.

div1.head: θοῦρος
div1.sense: rushing, raging, impetuous, furious, Il., Aesch.

div1.head: Θόωσα
div1.sense: speed, as prop. n., Od.

div1.head: Θρᾴκη
div1.sense: Thrace, Ar., Thuc., etc.: Ionic Θρηΐκη, Hdt.; Epic contr. Θρῄκη, Il., Trag.; Θρᾴκη in Ar.

div1.head: Θρᾴκιος
div1.sense: Thracian, Thuc., etc.: Ionic Θρηΐκιος, ος, η, ον, Il., Hdt.; contr. Θρῄκιος, Trag.:— Σάμος Θρηϊκίη Σαμοθρᾴκη, Il.

div1.head: Θρᾳκιστί
div1.sense: adv. in Thracian fashion, Theocr.

div1.head: θρανεύομαι
div1.sense: to be stretched on the tannerʼs board, to be tanned, Ar.

div1.head: θρανίτης
div1.sense: one of the rowers on the topmost of the three benches in a trireme, who had the longest oars and most work, a top-rower, Ar., Thuc.: —cf. ζυγίτης, θαλαμίτης.

div1.head: θρᾶνος
div1.sense: a bench, form, Ar.

div1.head: Θρᾷξ
div1.sense: a Thracian; Ionic Θρηΐξ, ΐκος, pl. Θρηΐκες [ῐ], Il., Hdt., etc.; Epic contr. Θρῇξ, Θρῃκός, Il., Trag., etc.

div1.head: θράσος
div1.sense: courage, boldness, Il., Soph.; θρ. ἰσχύος confidence in strength, Soph.
in bad sense, over-boldness, daring, rashness, audacity, impudence, Attic, Hdt.

div1.head: Θρᾷσσα
div1.sense: a Thracian woman, Soph., etc.

div1.head: θράσσω
div1.sense: to trouble, disquiet, Aesch., Eur., Plat., etc.
to destroy, ruin, Anth.

div1.head: θρασύβουλος
div1.sense: bold in counsel, Arist.

div1.head: θρασύγυιος
div1.sense: strong of limb, Pind.

div1.head: θρασύδειλος
div1.sense: an impudent coward, Arist.

div1.head: θρασυκάρδιος
div1.sense: bold of heart, Il.

div1.head: θρασύμαχος
div1.sense: bold in battle, Arist.

div1.head: θρασυμέμνων
div1.sense: bravely steadfast (cf. Μέμνων) , Hom.

div1.head: θρασυμήδης
div1.sense: bold of thought or plan, daring, resolute, Pind.

div1.head: θρασυμήχανος
div1.sense: bold in contriving, daring in design, Pind.

div1.head: θρασύμυθος
div1.sense: bold of speech, saucy, Pind.

div1.head: θρασύνω
div1.sense: = θαρσύνω, to make bold, embolden, encourage, Aesch., Thuc.:—Pass. and Mid., to be bold or ready, take courage, Aesch., Eur., etc.
Pass., in bad sense, to be over-bold, audacious, to speak boldly or insolently, Soph., Ar.

div1.head: θρασύπονος
div1.sense: bold or ready at work, Pind.

div1.head: θρασυπτόλεμος
div1.sense: bold in war, Anth.

div1.head: θρασύς
div1.sense: bold, spirited, courageous, confident, Hom., Hdt., Attic; θρασεῖα τοῦ μέλλοντος full of confidence for the future, Thuc.
in bad sense, over-bold, rash, venturous, Lat. audax, Od., Attic
of things, to be ventured, c. inf., θρασύ μοι τόδʼ εἰπεῖν this I am bold to say, Pind.; οὐκ ἆρʼ ἐκείνῳ προσμῖξαι θρασύ; Soph.
adv. -έως· comp. θρασύτερον, too boldly, Thuc.

div1.head: θρασύσπλαγχνος
div1.sense: bold-hearted, Eur. adv. -ως, Aesch.

div1.head: θρασυστομέω
div1.sense: to be over-bold of tongue, Trag.

div1.head: θρασυστομία
div1.sense: insolence, Anth.

div1.head: θρασύστομος
div1.sense: bold of tongue, insolent, Aesch.

div1.head: θρασύτης
div1.sense: over-boldness, audacity, Thuc.

div1.head: θρασύχειρ
div1.sense: bold of hand, Anth.

div1.head: θραυσάντυξ
div1.sense: breaking wheels, Ar.

div1.head: θραῦσμα
div1.sense: that which is broken, a fragment, wreck, piece, Aesch.

div1.head: θραύω
div1.sense: to break in pieces, shatter, shiver, Hdt., Aesch., Eur.:—Pass. to fly into pieces, Hdt.
metaph., like Lat. frangere, = θρύπτω, to break down, enfeeble, Pind., Eur., etc.

div1.head: θρέμμα
div1.sense: a nursling, creature, of sheep and goats, Xen., Plat.
of men, Soph., etc.
of wild beasts, Soph.
as a term of reproach, a creature, θρέμματʼ οὐκ ἀνασχετά Aesch.; ὦ θρέμμʼ ἀναιδές Soph.
ὕδρας θρ., periphr. for ὕδρα, Soph.

div1.head: θρέομαι
div1.sense: Dep., to cry aloud, shriek forth, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: θρεπτέος
div1.sense: to be fed, Plat.
θρεπτέον, one must feed, Xen.
from Pass., one must be fed, one must live, Xen.

div1.head: θρεπτήριος
div1.sense: able to feed or rear, feeding, nourishing, Aesch.
πλόκαμος θρ. hair let grow as an offering, Aesch.
θρεπτήρια, τά, rewards for rearing, Hhymn.; but also, the returns made by children for their rearing, Hes.
= τροφή, nourishment, Soph.

div1.head: θρεπτήρ
div1.sense: a feeder, rearer, Anth.

div1.head: θρεπτικός
div1.sense: promoting growth, Arist.; τὸ θρεπτικόν the principle of growth, Arist.

div1.head: θρέπτρα
div1.sense: the returns made by children to their parents for their rearing, Il.

div1.head: θρεττανελό
div1.sense: a sound imitative of the cithara (as tra lira of the horn), Ar.

div1.head: θρέττε
div1.sense: in Ar., οὐκ ἔνι μοι τὸ θρέττε, the spiritʼs not in me; a barbarism for τὸ θράσος.

div1.head: Θρῄκηθεν
div1.sense: from Thrace, Il.

div1.head: Θρῄκηνδε
div1.sense: to Thrace, Od.

div1.head: θρηνέω
div1.sense: to sing a dirge, to wail, Od., Aesch.:—c. acc. cogn., ἀοιδὴν ἐθρήνεον were singing a dirge, Il.; ὠιδάς, ἐπωιδάς θρ. Soph.:—Pass., ἅλις μοι τεθρήνηται, impers., Il.
c. acc. objecti, to wail for, lament, Aesch., etc.; so also Mid., Aesch.:—Pass. to be lamented, Soph.

div1.head: θρήνημα
div1.sense: a lament, dirge, Eur.

div1.head: θρηνητήρ
div1.sense: a mourner, wailer, Aesch.

div1.head: θρηνητικός
div1.sense: querulous, Arist.

div1.head: θρῆνος
div1.sense: a funeral-song, dirge, lament, Lat. naenia, Il., Hdt., Trag.; θρῆνος οὑμός for me, Aesch.
a complaint, sad strain, Pind., etc.

div1.head: θρῆνυς
div1.sense: a footstool, Hom.
θρ. ἑπταπόδης the seven-foot bench, the seat of the helmsman or the rowers, Il.

div1.head: θρηνῳδέω
div1.sense: to sing a dirge over, τινά Eur.

div1.head: θρηνώδης
div1.sense: like a dirge, fit for a dirge, Plat.

div1.head: θρηνῳδία
div1.sense: lamentation, Plat.

div1.head: θρηνῳδός
div1.sense: one who sings a dirge, Arist.

div1.head: θρησκεία
div1.sense: religious worship or usage, Hdt.: religion, NTest.; θρ. τῶν ἀγγέλων worshipping of angels, NTest.

div1.head: θρησκεύω
div1.sense: to hold religious observances, observe religiously, Hdt.
to be a devotee, Plut.

div1.head: θρῆσκος
div1.sense: religious, NTest.

div1.head: θριαμβευτικός
div1.sense: of triumphal families, Plut.

div1.head: θριαμβεύω
div1.sense: to triumph, Plut., etc.; θρ. ἀπό τινος or κατά τινος Lat. triumphare de aliquo, Plut.; also, θρ. τινά NTest.
to lead in triumph, τινά Plut.

div1.head: θριαμβικός
div1.sense: triumphal, ἀνὴρ θρ. Lat. vir triumphalis, Plut.

div1.head: θρίαμβος
div1.sense: a hymn to Bacchus, Cratin.: also a name for Bacchus, Plut., etc.
used to express the Roman triumphus, Plut.

div1.head: θριγκός
div1.sense: the topmost course of stones in a wall, which projected over the rest, the eaves, cornice, coping, Od., Eur.; θριγκὸς κυάνοιο a cornice of blue metal, Od.
metaph. the coping-stone, culmination, θριγκὸς κακῶν Eur.
a wall, fence of any sort, Eur.

div1.head: θριγκόω
div1.sense: to surround with a coping, αὐλὴν ἐθρίγκωσεν ἀχέρδῳ he fenced it at top with thornbushes, Od.
to build even to the copingstone: metaph. to put the finishing stroke to a thing, Aesch.; δῶμα κακοῖς θριγκοῦν to bring the house to the height of misery, Eur.

div1.head: θρίγκωμα
div1.sense: a coping, cornice, Eur.

div1.head: θριδάκινος
div1.sense: of lettuce, Luc.

div1.head: θρίδαξ
div1.sense: lettuce, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Θρινακίη
div1.sense: an old name of Sicily, from its three promontories, Od., etc.:—in later times, the old form Θρινακίη was altered into Τρινακρία, Lat. Trinacria, as if it were compounded of τρεῖς ἄκραι.

div1.head: θρῖναξ
div1.sense: a trident, Ar.

div1.head: θρίξ
div1.sense: the hair of the head, used by Hom. only in pl.; Attic also in sg.; Hom., etc.:—also sheepʼs wool, Il.; pigʼs bristles, Hom.; οὐραῖαι τρίχες the hair of a horseʼs tail, Il.
a single hair, proverb., θρὶξ ἀνὰ μέσσον only a hairʼs breadth between, Theocr.; ἄξιον τριχός, i. e. good for nothing, Ar.

div1.head: θρῖον
div1.sense: a fig-leaf, Ar.
a mixture of eggs, milk, lard, flour, honey, and cheese, a kind of omelette, so called because it was wrapped in figleaves, Ar.
div1.etym: Prob. from τρίς, from the three lobes of the figleaf.

div1.head: θρίψ
div1.sense: a wood-worm, Anth.

div1.head: θροέω
div1.sense: to cry aloud, Soph.:— to speak, say, utter, Trag.;—and in Mid., Aesch.
to tell out, declare, Aesch., Soph.
Pass. to be troubled, NTest.

div1.head: θρόμβος
div1.sense: a lump, piece, Lat. grumus, as of asphalt, Hdt.: a clot or gout of blood, Aesch.

div1.head: θρομβώδης
div1.sense: like clots, clotted, Soph.

div1.head: θρόνον
div1.sense: flowers embroidered on cloth, patterns, Il.
flowers or herbs used as drugs and charms, Theocr.

div1.head: θρόνος
div1.sense: a seat, chair, Hom.: a throne, chair of state, Hdt., Attic:—in pl. also, the throne, i. e. the kingʼs estate or dignity, Soph.
the oracular seat of Apollo or the Pythia, Aesch., etc.
the chair of a teacher, Lat. cathedra, Plat.

div1.head: θρόνωσις
div1.sense: the enthronement of the newly initiated at the mysteries, Plat.

div1.head: θρόος
div1.sense: a noise as of many voices, Il.; of musical sounds, Pind.
the murmuring of a crowd, Thuc.
a report, Lat. rumor, Xen.

div1.head: θρυαλλίς
div1.sense: a plant which, like our rush, was used for making wicks, a wick, Ar.

div1.head: θρυλέω
div1.sense: to make a confused noise, chatter, babble, Ar., Theocr.
c. acc. rei, to be always talking about a thing, repeat over and over again, Lat. decantare, Eur., Plat., etc.:— Pass., τὸ θρυλούμενον the common talk, what is in every oneʼs mouth, Dem.

div1.head: θρυλίζω
div1.sense: to make a false note, Hhymn.

div1.head: θρυλίσσω
div1.sense: to crush, shiver, smash:— Pass., θρυλίχθη δὲ μέτωπον (Epic for ἐθρυλίχθη) Il.

div1.head: θρῦλος
div1.sense: a noise as of many voices, a shouting, murmuring, Batr.

div1.head: θρύμμα
div1.sense: that which is broken off, a piece, bit, Ar., Anth.

div1.head: θρύον
div1.sense: a rush, Lat. juncus, Il.

div1.head: θρυπτικός
div1.sense: easily broken: metaph. delicate, effeminate, Xen.

div1.head: θρύπτω
div1.sense: to break in pieces, break small, Plat., Theocr.
metaph., like Lat. frangere, to break, crush, enfeeble: Pass., with fut. mid., to be enfeebled, enervated, unmanned, Xen.; τεθρυμμένος Luc.
in Pass. also, to play the coquet, be coy and prudish, give oneself airs, bridle up, Ar., Xen.; θρύπτεσθαι πρός τινα to give oneself airs toward him, Plut.

div1.head: θρύψις
div1.sense: a breaking in small pieces:—metaph. softness, weakness, debauchery, Xen., Plut., etc.

div1.head: θρῴσκω
div1.etym: From Root !θορ, which appears in fut. and aor2.
div1.sense: to leap, spring, ἐκ δίφροιο, ἀπὸ λέκτροιο Hom.; of arrows, ἀπὸ νευρῆφι θρῶσκον Il.; of the oar, Soph.
foll. by prep. to leap upon, i. e. attack, assault, ἐπὶ Τρώεσσι θόρον Il.: —of a recurring illness, to attack, Soph.
generally, to rush, dart, Pind., Soph.:—metaph., πεδάρσιοι θρώσκουσι leap up into air, i. e. vanish away, Aesch.
trans. to mount, ὁ θρώσκων the sire, Aesch.

div1.head: θρωσμός
div1.sense: ground rising from the plain, an eminence, Il.

div1.head: θυγάτηρ
div1.sense: a daughter, Hom., etc.

div1.head: θυγατριδῆ
div1.sense: a daughterʼs daughter, granddaughter, Attic

div1.head: θυγατριδοῦς
div1.sense: a daughterʼs son, grandson, Attic; Ionic -ιδέος, Hdt.

div1.head: θυεία
div1.sense: a mortar, Ar.

div1.head: θύελλα
div1.sense: a furious storm, hurricane, Hom.; πυρὸς θύελλαι thunderstorms, Od.; ποντία θ. Soph.; metaph., ἄτης θύελλαι Aesch.

div1.head: Θυέστειος
div1.sense: of Thyestes, Ar.

div1.head: θυηδόχος
div1.sense: receiving incense, Anth.

div1.head: θυήεις
div1.sense: smoking or smelling with incense, fragrant, Hom., Hes.

div1.head: θυηλή
div1.sense: the part of the victim that was burnt, the primal offering, mostly in pl., Il., Ar.:—metaph., θυηλὴ Ἄρεος, an offering to Ares, i. e. the blood of the slain, Soph.

div1.head: θυηπολέω
div1.sense: to busy oneself with sacrifices, Aesch., Eur.
trans. to sacrifice:—Pass., θυηπολεῖται δʼ ἄστυ is filled with sacrifices, Eur.

div1.head: θυηπόλος
div1.sense: busy about sacrifices, sacrificial, Aesch.:—as Subst. a diviner, soothsayer, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: θυηφάγος
div1.sense: devouring offerings, Aesch.

div1.head: θυία
div1.sense: an African tree with scented wood, a kind of juniper or cedar, Theophr.

div1.head: θυιάς
div1.sense: a mad or inspired woman, a Bacchante, Aesch.

div1.head: θύϊνος
div1.sense: of the tree θυία, of cedar, NTest.

div1.head: θυίω
div1.sense: to be inspired, Hhymn.

div1.head: θυλάκιον
div1.sense: a little bag, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: θύλακος
div1.sense: a bag, pouch, wallet, Hdt., Ar.; δερῶ σε θύλακον Iʼll make a bag of your skin, Ar.
in pl. the trousers of the Persians, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: θύλημα
div1.sense: that which is offered; mostly in pl. θυλήματα, cakes, incense, etc., Ar.

div1.head: θυμαίνω
div1.sense: to be wroth, angry, Hes., Ar.

div1.head: θυμαλγής
div1.sense: heart-grieving, Hom., Hdt.
pass. inly grieving, καρδία Aesch.

div1.head: θυμάλωψ
div1.sense: a piece of burning wood or charcoal, a hot coal, Ar.

div1.head: θῦμα
div1.sense: that which is slain or offered, a victim, sacrifice, offering, Trag., Thuc., etc.; πάγκαρπα θ. offerings of all fruits, Soph.
sacrifice, as an act, Soph.: metaph., θ. λεύσιμον a sacrifice to be avenged by stoning [the murderers], Aesch.

div1.head: θυμαρέω
div1.sense: to be well-pleased, Theocr.

div1.head: θυμαρής
div1.sense: suiting the heart, i. e. well-pleasing, dear, delightful, Hom.:—neut. as adv. in the form θυμῆρες, Od.

div1.head: θύμβρα
div1.sense: a bitter herb, savory, Eupol.

div1.head: θυμβρεπίδειπνος
div1.sense: supping on bitter herbs, i. e. living poorly, Ar.

div1.head: Θύμβρις
div1.sense: the Tiber, Anth.

div1.head: θυμβροφάγος
div1.sense: eating savory, θυμβροφάγον βλέπειν to look as if one had eaten savory, make a savory or (as we might say) a verjuice face, Ar.

div1.head: θυμέλη
div1.sense: a place for sacrifice, an altar, Aesch., Eur.
θυμέλαι Κυκλώπων, supposed to be the Cyclopian walls at Mycenae, Eur.
in the Athenian theatre, a platform in the orchestra, on the steps of which stood the leader of the chorus, Plut.:— generally, a raised seat or stage, Plut.

div1.head: θυμελικός
div1.sense: of or for the thymele, scenic, theatric, Plut.:— οἱ θυμελικοί, i. e. the chorus or musicians, Plut.

div1.head: θυμηγερέων
div1.etym: a part. with no pres. in use
div1.sense: gathering breath, collecting oneself, Od.

div1.head: θυμηδής
div1.sense: well-pleasing, Od., Aesch.

div1.head: θυμίαμα
div1.sense: that which is burnt as incense: in pl. fragrant stuffs for burning, Hdt., Soph., etc.
stuff for embalming, Hdt.

div1.head: θυμιατήριον
div1.sense: a vessel for burning incense, a censer, Hdt., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: θυμιάω
div1.sense: to burn so as to produce smoke, burn, Hdt.:—Pass. to be burnt, 3rd sg. θυμιῆται (Ionic for -ᾶται) Hdt.

div1.head: θυμικός
div1.sense: high-spirited, passionate, Arist.

div1.head: θυμίτης
div1.sense: flavoured with thyme, Ar.

div1.head: θυμοβαρής
div1.sense: heavy at heart, Anth.

div1.head: θυμοβορέω
div1.sense: to gnaw or vex the heart, Hes.

div1.head: θυμοβόρος
div1.sense: eating the heart, Il.

div1.head: θυμοδακής
div1.sense: biting the heart, Od., Anth.

div1.head: θυμοειδής
div1.sense: high-spirited, courageous, Lat. animosus, Plat., Xen.
hot-tempered, restive, Xen.

div1.head: θυμολέων
div1.sense: lion-hearted, coeur-de-lion, Il.

div1.head: θυμόμαντις
div1.sense: prophesying from oneʼs own soul (without inspiration, like the θεόμαντις) , Aesch.

div1.head: θυμομαχέω
div1.sense: to fight desperately, NTest., Plut.

div1.head: θύμον
div1.sense: thyme, Ar., etc.
a mixture of thyme with honey and vinegar, Ar.

div1.head: θυμοπληθής
div1.sense: wrathful, Aesch.

div1.head: θυμοραϊστής
div1.sense: life-destroying, Il.

div1.head: θυμοσοφικός
div1.sense: like a clever fellow, Ar.

div1.head: θυμόσοφος
div1.sense: wise from oneʼs own soul, i. e. naturally clever, a man of genius, Ar., Plut.

div1.head: θυμός
div1.sense: the soul:

like Lat. anima, the soul, breath, life, θυμὸν ἀπαυρᾶν, ἀφελέσθαι, ἐξελέσθαι, ἐξαίνυσθαι, ὀλέσαι to take away life, Hom.; θυμὸν ἀποπνείειν to expire, Il.; θυμὸν ἀγείρειν to collect oneself, Il., etc.; θυμὸς τείρετο καμάτῳ his spirit was wearied by toil, Il.
like Lat. animus, the soul, heart; and so,

of desire for meat and drink, ἔπιον θʼ ὅσον ἤθελε θυμός Il.:—c. inf., βαλέειν δέ ἑ θυμὸς ἀνώγει his heart bade him shoot, Il.; ἤθελε θυμῷ he wished in his heart or with all his heart, Il.; θυμῷ βουλόμενος wishing with all oneʼs heart, Hdt.; so, ἐκ θυμοῦ φιλέειν Il.:— θυμός ἐστί μοι, θ. γίγνεταί μοι, c. inf., I have a mind to do . . , Il., Xen., etc.:—also as the seat of sorrow or joy, χαῖρε δὲ θυμῷ Il.; ἄχνυτο θυμός Il., etc.

mind, temper, will, θ. πρόφρων, νηλεής, σιδήρεος Hom.; ἕνα θυμὸν ἔχειν to be of one mind, Il.; δόκησε δʼ ἄρα σφίσι θυμὸς ὣς ἔμεν it pleased them to be of this mind, Od.; ἐδαΐζετο θωμός their mind was divided, Il.
spirit, courage, μένος καὶ θυμός Il.; θυμὸν λαμβάνειν to take heart, Od.; παραὶ ποσὶ κάππεσε θυμός Il., etc.
as the seat of anger, νεμεσίζεσθαι ἐνὶ θυμῷ Il.:—hence, anger, wrath, δάμασον θυμόν Il.; θυμὸς μέγας ἐστὶ βασιλῆος Il.
the soul as the agent of thought, ᾔδεε γὰρ κατὰ θυμόν Il.; φράζετο θυμῷ Il.

div1.head: θυμοφθορέω
div1.sense: to torment the soul, break the heart, Soph.

div1.head: θυμοφθόρος
div1.sense: destroying the soul, life-destroying, Od.:— heart-breaking, Od.; of persons, troublesome, annoying, Od.:— θυμοφθόρα πολλά (sc. σήματα) tokens poisoning the kingʼs mind (against Bellerophon), Il.

div1.head: θυμόω
div1.sense: to make angry:—Mid. and Pass., fut. -ώσομαι; aor1 ἐθυμωσάμην and ἐθυμώθην· perf. inf. τεθυμῶσθαι:— to be wroth or angry, absol., Hdt., Trag.; of animals, to be wild, restive, Soph.; θυμοῦσθαι εἰς κέρας to vent fury with the horns, Virgilʼs irasci in cornua, Eur.; τὸ θυμούμενον passion, Thuc.: —θυμοῦσθαί τινι to be angry with one, Aesch., etc.; εἴς τινα Hdt.; c. dat. rei, to be angry at a thing, Ar.

div1.head: θύμωμα
div1.sense: wrath, passion, Aesch.

div1.head: θυνέω
div1.sense: to dart along, Hes.

div1.head: θυννάζω
div1.sense: to spear a tunny-fish, Ar.

div1.head: θύννειος
div1.sense: of the tunny-fish: τὰ θύννεια (sc. κρέα) its flesh, Ar.

div1.head: θυννευτικός
div1.sense: for tunny-fishing, Luc.

div1.head: θυννοκέφαλος
div1.sense: tunny-headed, Luc.

div1.head: θυννοσκοπέω
div1.sense: to watch for tunnies, Ar.

div1.head: θυννοσκόπος
div1.sense: a tunny-watcher, i. e. one who was posted on a high place, from which he could see the shoals coming, and make a sign to the fisherman to let down their nets, Theocr.

div1.head: θύννος
div1.sense: the tunny-fish, a large fish, used for food in the Mediterranean, Orac. ap. Hdt., Aesch., etc.
div1.etym: From θύνω, because of the tunaʼs quick, darting motion.

div1.head: θύνω
div1.sense: to rush or dart along, mostly of warriors in battle, Hom., Pind.

div1.head: θυοδόκος
div1.sense: receiving incense, full thereof, odorous, Eur.

div1.head: θυόεις
div1.sense: laden with incense, odorous, fragrant, Il., Eur.

div1.head: θύον
div1.sense: a tree, the wood of which was burnt as a perfume, Od.

div1.head: θυοσκέω
